124256772.reviewBody: It was very interesting and they have a great museum there.  Not too far away is Aqua Azul.  Both are worth the visit.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

123991230.name: Another grand ruin.
123991230.author: a TripAdvisor user
123991230.reviewBody: Really, simply got a guide at the ruins. They wanted FAR more than we paid... haggle a bit. Our guide was Raul. Kind of a hippie, but reallly knowledgeable

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

123945493.name: Unique in the Maya World
123945493.author: a TripAdvisor user
123945493.reviewBody:
The Palenque Archaeological Park is located approximately 9 km from town and is easily reached by taxi or bus.  If you are driving or taking a taxi you will have to pay a M$20 park toll per person at the park entrance gate, located about one km before the ruins.  You will also be offered a nice map of the site at a modest price, which I would recommend you purchase.  The admission to the ruins at the entrance is modest, M$85 and the entrance fee to the site museum is included in the entrance fee.

The site differs from many other Maya sites in a number of ways, for instance there is no central plaza or acropolis, and the ball court seems relatively modest for such a large site.  The famous four-storied tower that may have been a lookout or observatory is unusual, and the interesting vaulted water delivery system is unlike any I have seen.   

The best experience is to come upon the ruins in the early morning hours, as the park opens at 8 am, to find the temples covered by mist in the lovely jungle setting.  For this reason alone, it is worth staying overnight in town.  The largest and best-preserved ruins are in the Principle Group, the area you will come upon if you enter by the main entrance.  The first building to your right is the Temple of the Inscriptions, the tomb of King Pakal, located deep inside the pyramid.  Unfortunately, the tomb is closed to the public.  

After the main group, you can walk through the rain forest down a lovely paved path, which leads to lesser buildings, a charming area with waterfalls and pools that should not be missed.  The paved path leads downhill to the exit/secondary entrance close by the museum.  The museum, which is closed on Mondays, gives one a greater understanding of the people who inhabited Palenque and is well worth seeing.  Don’t miss the fabulous incense burners, which were found at the site.

Regular transportation back to town leaves from the museum/restaurant area.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

123702080.name: Mystical exploration
123702080.author: a TripAdvisor user
123702080.reviewBody: my favourite of all , its mystical and well conserved all in a spectacular location . Take your time .

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

123333681.name: Kim\'s Tours is the pick in Palenque
123333681.author: a TripAdvisor user
123333681.reviewBody: We visited the Mayan ruins, Agua Azul and Misol Ha with Kim\'s tours for 300pesos (15gbp) and all were such good value we went on a full day tour next day. The ruins at Palenque are a must see but if you have a guide book e.g. Lonely Planet don\'t bother with a guide in the ruins as all have English explanations.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

123066648.name: One of the most beautiful Mayan sites
123066648.author: a TripAdvisor user
123066648.reviewBody: It\'s a beautiful park full of the kind of ruins that have inspired so many movies and theme park rides. It\'s truly one of the highlights of any visit to Mexico. We have been told that a guided tour can really help you understand the place much better and they seem to be quite affordable too. I guess we were stupid not make use of this opportunity. However, we still very much enjoyed the park and were greatly impressed by the sheer size of the buildings and temples.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

122912682.name: A must see
122912682.author: a TripAdvisor user
122912682.reviewBody: I cannot possibly describe how it feels to be lost in this park...all those buildings combined with the surrounding nature almost made me cry:)

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

122871566.name: Visit many times
122871566.author: a TripAdvisor user
122871566.reviewBody: definately talk to the Lacandon Indians outside. I got some interesting information from them. We like to mingle and buy their food.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

122663813.name: Just Fantastic
122663813.author: a TripAdvisor user
122663813.reviewBody: This is completely different from Chichen Itza and Uxmal so gives an extra dimension to the Mayan history.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

122353210.name: You don\'t need to pay for an expensive Tour
122353210.author: a TripAdvisor user
122353210.reviewBody:
The ruins are a short drive from town. You can hail a minibus from the street (just look for one with a "ruinas" sign in the front windscreen). It will cost you a few pesos and is very easy. Get the driver to drop you at the museum, and go and have a look there first - the temptation is always to run straight to the ruins - but actually this is one of the better Maya museums and goes a long way towards explaining the site. 

Then it's a short 2 min walk to the site entrance, where you climb stone stairs through the jungle. It's magical, feeling like a lost world. Most people seemed to take the left fork in the path, we took the right fork and felt like we had the forest and the site to ourselves. 

The site itself is just beautiful, I'd rate it as more beautiful than Tikal or Copan Ruinas. It's not the biggest, but there are some wonderful touches, not least the intact roofcombs and the occasional scrap of painted decorative flower in the palace. 

And take some food and  water - sounds obvious but the everything was closed when we went and we were very grateful for our bottle of water and snacks, 

If you do decide to take a tour, I'd recommend paying for your entry ticket yourself and asking for  your ticket - just to ensure the money does indeed go to the site.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

122290766.name: Ruins in the jungle
122290766.author: a TripAdvisor user
122290766.reviewBody: This was different to other mexican ruins we had seen as it was in the lovely jungle.  We started at the top entrance and walked downhill- which I would thoroughly recommend as it gets pretty hot and walking uphill is tiring.  The walk takes you through the stunning ruins and also past some pretty waterfalls. Get there before 10am though, as the place gets super busy.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

122086927.name: Absolutely stunning
122086927.author: a TripAdvisor user
122086927.reviewBody: Amazing to see.  How anyone could create such things today would be amazing never mind so long ago.  It was wonderful to see so many Mayan sites and to see how wide their empire was.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

121967508.name: Fascinating Ruins in the Jungle
121967508.author: a TripAdvisor user
121967508.reviewBody:
Palenque is an amazing treasure hidden in the forest.  The main ruins are well excavated and the area is not very big.  If you explore the peripheral ruins you can really walk a long ways.  Some reviewers have complained about the vendors but they were pretty low-key compared to Chichen Itza or Teotihuacan. 

My only complaint is that there is only one bathroom facility and it's toward the back of the park.

Definitely take the walk to the "Murcielago" ruins in the back of the park and check out the amazing waterfall.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

121823566.name: Interesting and humid place
121823566.author: a TripAdvisor user
121823566.reviewBody: We spent a few hours in this site and enjoyed it very much

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

121681011.name: Interesting
121681011.author: a TripAdvisor user
121681011.reviewBody: I liked this site.  I walked around it and took many photos.  I would recommend it as a place to see.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

121635131.name: The cradle of mayan civilization
121635131.author: a TripAdvisor user
121635131.reviewBody: This place is a site you must see before you die. While in this site you will still feel the power of the amazing and magnificent mayan culture, and all what they left for us. The pyramids, the historical sites, the tumbs, Pakal and all it\'s power, their knowledge about the universe, architecture, physics, life and death, mathematics, etc.\nPlease go to this archeoligical site, if you are the type of person who likes mexican culture and want to learn about the mayan civilization, it\'s a life changing experience.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

121598847.name: very impressive
121598847.author: a TripAdvisor user
121598847.reviewBody: I will go back tomorrow for a second visit as there is so much to see

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

120875662.name: Amazing ruins
120875662.author: a TripAdvisor user
120875662.reviewBody: Shouldn\'t miss these ruins. Hire a guide - we would have missed so much with one.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

120549461.name: Must see!
120549461.author: a TripAdvisor user
120549461.reviewBody: Go early before the crowds arrive.  If time allows go on a nature walk with one of the guides.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

120504238.name: Incredible ruin
120504238.author: a TripAdvisor user
120504238.reviewBody: Get there early, right when it opens.  And, head right away for the pyramids at the back for a great view of the site before it is crowded with people.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

120442078.name: Palenque
120442078.author: a TripAdvisor user
120442078.reviewBody: The Ruins are well preserved and the site is huge. Only a portion of it has been restored-excavated.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

120416312.name: Worth the visit
120416312.author: a TripAdvisor user
120416312.reviewBody: Liked the historical significance and the site, which was a huge park with lots of trees.\nDid not like the constant pestering of the souvenir vendors nor the $80/hr price for a guide.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

119927647.name: one of the top of my journey in Mexico
119927647.author: a TripAdvisor user
119927647.reviewBody: Ruins inside forest jungle, it is amazing to know that only 10% of ruina was excavated, and rest is still uncovered

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

119903786.name: Palenque well worth the time
119903786.author: a TripAdvisor user
119903786.reviewBody: Palenque is set amid a lush jungle and is well worth the visit.  About a two hour drive from Villahermosa you can easily do the tour in a day including Bonampark.  Or go to Palenque and then continue on to some of the Mayan-run eco-camps another hour away.  The steps on the ruins are very slippery so be careful when exploring.  It\'s a bit bothersome that vendors are allowed to sell things within the site itself, but they are low key.  However it might be better to buy things from the stands outside the entrance fee area.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

119809402.name: Best Mayan site
119809402.author: a TripAdvisor user
119809402.reviewBody: Loved the setting, the place & the ruins. Definitely a must-do in Mexico!

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

119412227.name: The most mystical and enchanting place I have ever been
119412227.author: a TripAdvisor user
119412227.reviewBody: I have been to Palenque several times.  Each time I am struck dumb by the majesty and surrounding beauty of this place.  The palace with it\'s four story tower seems to defy time and logic.  The howls of monkeys in the back sound like lions and the jungle just beyond the clearings looks like it might swallow you.  And yet in the midst of this there stands this fantastic city, still standing so many hundreds of years later.  Find a guide that will tell you some of the stories, or buy a book before hand so you know some of what took place here.  Sit on the steps and try to absorb some of this world that you are getting a glimpse of.  Whatever you do, you should go, no excuses, because it\'s no exaggeration that this is the most awe inspiring place I have ever been.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

118270937.name: WOW!!!
118270937.author: a TripAdvisor user
118270937.reviewBody: Amazing place!!!  We took a Colectivo here, and it was very cheap and easy to do.  Definitely go with the Colectivo rather than a tour company. Tour companies charge much more and you are on a schedule.  Our bus arrived and we were immediately approached by fellas wanting to give us a tour.  Since it was low season, a man named Gilberto came up to us, offered us a tour of Palenque for 150 pesos for my boyfriend and me.  We took him up on the offer and were so glad we did.  He provided such cool information and made the tour so much more enjoyable.  Tour was about 2 hours.  These ruins are surrounded by jungle and after the last ruin in the tour, we walked through the path of the jungle surround by lush greenery and waterfalls.  WOW!!! Such a gorgeous place.  Definitely one of the highlights of my two week stay in Chiapas.  I highly recommend and will visit again.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

118092922.name: amazing , beautiful ruins
118092922.author: a TripAdvisor user
118092922.reviewBody: The ruins bring the history of these people to life.  the ruins are spectacular and amazing.   The temples are not be missed.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

118000651.name: A magic place
118000651.author: a TripAdvisor user
118000651.reviewBody: This is an historic, magnificent place. Palenque is one of the best Mexican wonders, it was awesome to be there.  It is surrounded by jungle trees and  there are like 5 buildings (ruins) to watch. You should hire a guide to understand the buildings and what they serve for. Entrance is like 51mexican pesos which will be around 5 dlls  per person. You can take pictures (without any flash). If you want to take video you will have to pay around 5 dlls more. I paid for it and worth it, I can review every detail I recorded from that magical place. You cannot enter any food, you can only enter your water bottle. Get your outdoor shoes and your insect repellent. To enjoy this adventure you will need to climb some of the ruins, so be careful if you are taking kids or older people since, the experience involves walking a lot of the time.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

117515896.name: My favorite ruin in all Mexico
117515896.author: a TripAdvisor user
117515896.reviewBody:
I like it much better than Chichen Itza and would choose it if I could only see one. Was my third time. 
There are several ways to get to the main site and you should try to come one way and go back the other way which allows to see many other remains in the woods - a nice stroll. If your physical condition allows you, do not take the shuttle or you'll miss all that. It is only a 15 mn walk maximum.
Take plenty of water because it is very hot here and there are many pyramids to climb. If I remember right bathrooms are only at the museum, very far from the site, so make sure you go there before you start because you might stay up there longer than you thought.
Some of the artwork are to be found only on this site - if you like it, buy it, don't wait for the next pyramid, you might not see it again in Yucatan.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

117481064.name: Crowded between Christmas and New Years but so what !
117481064.author: a TripAdvisor user
117481064.reviewBody: I am not an archaeologist but I have an addiction for the archaeological sites in Mexico and central America. We have slowly been working our way through them one by one and I have to say that Palenque lived up to the hype. It\'s beauty is incomparable with an amazing jungle backdrop. You will not be disappointed. So many of the ruins you can actually walk into, the tricky part was getting pictures without the crowds in the background. That took some creative camera work, but the grounds are so extensive that you can easily wander through and end up at some spots all alone. We visited a few days after Christmas 2010 arriving late ( so we missed the early morning howler monkeys)  due to a long night at a karaoke bar and gnarly hangover. At 9:30 in the morning the drive up the hill was massively locked by buses and minivans , completely saturated with tourists. I have never seen so much activity at an archaeological site EVER !!! Not only great ruins but also a great place to people watch, I had an appreciation for watching the vendors hustling and the indigenous women balancing heavy loads ofmerchandise on their heads while rushing every prospect. FOOD: We had a jammin\' meal at Palenque at a street vendor selling tamales wrapped in banana leaf. They had a smoky flavor, that I am craving even as I write this. Don\'t miss out, it is always worth risking a little diarrhea for a potential epic meal. Although still be careful , if you have read any of my other review for Palenque area, my son picked up Giardia and Amoeba, and got such a bad case of the runs it sounded like a horse pissing not someone going number 2.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

116649433.name: Wonderfull, thoroughly enjoyed visit
116649433.author: a TripAdvisor user
116649433.reviewBody: Started our day at 8 O\'clock, and took 5 hours to visit the site. Advise to read about the site before visiting, maps available. We did not take a guide because they will show you around in 2 hrs and we do not like that pace. There are plenty of groups walking around with guide and we just listened in (interesting in the Palace). The museum is worth a visit, remember to take enough to drink,  drinks only sold at entrance and departure. this site is uncovered from the rainforest and when you climb a temple you have a good overview of the site. It is worth taking the walk through the forest to the museum.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

116347264.name: One of the places you have to visit before you die...
116347264.author: a TripAdvisor user
116347264.reviewBody:
Mayan ruins located in the middle of the Mexican jungle.    I think is the most beautiful archeological zone in Mexico.  The blend of the jungle and the ruins, the Mayan mistery, the culture of different ethnical groups.    

It used to be an important Mayan city and only 2% has been explored!   You could even discover a new pyramid if you are adventurous enough !

People is extremely friendly and local food is an adventure by itself.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

105708744.name: Impressive Ancient Ruins
105708744.author: a TripAdvisor user
105708744.reviewBody: Unlike some other ancient Mexican ruins, the ruins at Palenque can be walked on. By doing this it gives people a better perspective and understanding of how skilled the ancient Maya people were. We spent a full morning at the site but much more time could easily have been spent there. Palenque was occupied around 100BC and the skill of the people at that time was incredible. Take plenty of water, sunscreen and a hat when visitng this site because it takes hours to see this site properly.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

101585904.name: Great jungle setting
101585904.author: a TripAdvisor user
101585904.reviewBody: Palenque just feels the most authentic of all the Maya sites. Beautiful jungle setting. Current price (March 2011) is MXN 50 for park entrance + MXN 51 per person.\n\nIt takes a while to get there, at least from Yucatan. We drove from Chetumal and it took us 5,5 hours. We stopped in (Fernando) Escarcega for lunch, a very good lunch stop (not much else there though).

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

94767635.name: Amazing Jungle Ruins
94767635.author: a TripAdvisor user
94767635.reviewBody:
I had read about some of the security issues in the state of Chiapas and I was a little concerned about traveling in this area. I am very aware of security issues and I saw absolutely nothing that made me feel the least bit uncomfortable while in Chiapas. 
   We woke up in the city of Palenque and headed towards the ruins to arrive soon after they opened.  We stopped at a checkpoint and paid to enter the Palenque National Park, we then drove about 10 more minutes to the entrance to the ruins. There are many souvenir and food booths near the entrance and because we arrived early, we were able to park very close to the gate. I paid a few pesos to have someone “watch my car.” Of course this isn’t necessary, but I don’t mind spreading a little wealth eighty cents at a time.
   You buy the tickets a few hundred feet from the gate at a hut hidden among the booths and then head for the entrance.  It’s a short walk before you are presented with a row of pyramids with the thick jungle as a backdrop. The first pyramid to the right was extremely slippery from the mud that was being tracked up the steps. There wasn’t much to see from this pyramid, but it was there, so we climbed it. The next pyramid had an entrance halfway up the central stairs and it was interesting to be able to explore the corridors inside. My favorite feature of Palenque is the “Palace,” the central tower looks more like something that you would see in Asia than Mexico. There were a few more temples and pyramids to climb and the only one that you are not able to climb is the Temple of Inscriptions. Most of the stairs are very steep but the views from the top were really beautiful. There is also a good bit of open ground to walk around and take in different views of the ruins. From any direction you immediately knew that you were not in the US, the trees, plants and birds were all very tropical. We saw a couple of toucans flying, something that we had never seen before.
   There were a lot of indigenous vendors with their art displayed on blankets among the ruins; they were not pushy like they tend to be at other sites. As we exited we stopped at a couple of booths and bought water and fruit and the best chicken tamales that I had ever had in my life. We took the advice given in a couple of books which said that eating from street vendors is not only safe, but it provides a real cultural experience, an opportunity to interact with interesting people, and the money goes to the people who need it the most and they are very appreciative of your business.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

65591516.name: A Lost World in the Jungle
65591516.author: a TripAdvisor user
65591516.reviewBody:
The site is a huge sprawling complex of Mayan burial sites, of which about 10% has been properly uncovered. The pyramids and buildings on display are incredible and with the relatively few tourists on the site (we saw about 20) it really feels like you have the place to yourself. 

The site has a good walk which takes you around the uncovered buildings and sites through the jungle and past a series of small waterfalls, but for a true experience hire and guide and have them take you on a walk through the rainforest to see the buildings which are still beneath the vines and trees. 

Magical experience

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

47302800.name: More "hands on" than Chichen Itza
47302800.author: a TripAdvisor user
47302800.reviewBody: The great thing about Palenque is, unlike Chichen Itza, you are still allowed to walk up the pyramids etc. This makes it a much more hands on experience than Chichen where all the ruins are roped off.\nMy number one tip is to bring water with with you. Despite the hundreds of sellers around the ruins I couldn\'t find one that sold water and it gets very hot and humid there!

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

44845500.name: Amazing ruins. Mayas were just great intelligent people
44845500.author: a TripAdvisor user
44845500.reviewBody: Only one suggestion. Visit them and you\'ll be amazed.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

17958560.name: Palenque Chiapas Mexico
17958560.author: a TripAdvisor user
17958560.reviewBody: The National Park of Palenque is absolutely beautiful and in my opinion, does not compare to any other ruins in Mexico. You are allowed to to climb one ruin which I highly recommend. The view of the city is perfect and worth the climb. As you make your way down to the museum, the waterfalls are amazing. Clear blue water and very refreshing after walking and sweating for a few hours.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

15389817.name: The Most Enchanting Location Ever
15389817.author: a TripAdvisor user
15389817.reviewBody:
Palenque is the place I now long to go back to more than anywhere I've ever been in the world. A friend of mine who had visited there some years ago urged me to go there on a recent trip to Mexico and it was by far the highlight of the entire trip by a mile and then some.

Completely off the beaten path and nestled  in the middle of the jungle is the most amazing setting I have ever beheld. Imagine undulating land, steamy and luscious jungle spotted with howler monkey's and the most gracious ruins rising majestically from the bright grassy hills and shrouded in early morning mist. Sounds too good to be true - but it isn't. Besides the visual feast of towering elephant ear's, palm trees, mosses and creepers, a veritable rainbow of butterflies decorates the cascading green like multi-coloured Christmas decorations. 

Breaking the silence, Howler Monkeys - who rule these forests - bring the canopy to life and can be seen at all times of day (though they seem to prefer howling earlier and later in the day). If you don't know what these Monkey's sound like check out this online mp3 http://www.naturesongs.com/howler5.wav - apparently they're the loudest mammal in the world - and definitely with the eeriest sound. Their roar echoes through the jungle and commands even the smallest of creatures attention. Keep your eyes peeled on the upper-most canopy and you'll be sure to see these rather small dark friends swinging from branch to branch; if you're lucky with a baby or two on their backs.

Then there are the ruins; as you follow the path up into the park the trees suddenly clear and on a sunny day, the light reflects brilliantly off the first stretch of pyramids. This is truly a majestic place. The pyramids seem to soar out from the earth, touching the sky and taking their rule over this area of jungle.

When my partner and I went it was rather quiet, by way of tourists, and we  spent an entire day climbing every pyramid on site and taking 100s upon 100s of photos. Be ready for a workout if you're up for it, as you're still able to climb and explore pretty much every monument in this park. We didn't bother with a guide but eavesdropped on a few talks given by local archaeologists and discovered some amazing facts about the site. If I had it over to do again (which i plan to as soon as i have more dollars in my piggy-bank) I would have looked into paying a qualified archaeologist to take me for a guided tour.  Apparently the site is still actively being worked on so there are a few archaeologists in the area who are happy to give guided tours. 

One of the most amazing aspects on this park is the fact that you can actually walk deep into the buildings which are dark, moist and dimly lit - but oh-so-fascinating. Be sure to keep an eye out for their ancient toilets (very interesting!), the tomb of Pakal's mother and also look out for the remnants of original paint which can be seen as blue and red flecks, particularly in the upper most eaves of the structures. There's an old national geographic which reconstructs an image of Palenque as it would have looked in it's heyday - mighty and statuesque in it's rich terracotta red and trimmed in a royal blue - look out for this pinned to the wall of the Internet cafe at El Panchan. 

Palenque is truly a destination worth visiting and I simply can not wait to go back there. To top off the experience stay at El Panchan and you will not be disappointed!

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

14305340.name: Best ruins in Mexico
14305340.author: a TripAdvisor user
14305340.reviewBody:
Overview:

I visited these ruins 2 years ago, but looking at the reviews listed I found some detail missing, so I am writing this review now.  First of all I truely enjoyed my time at Palenque.  I have seen several ruins in Mexico (Tulum, Chichen Itza, Coba, Monte Alban and others) and Palenque is the best by far (although the others are nice, too.).  Only Tikal in Guatemala beats it as far as Mayan ruins go.

What makes this ruin so spectacular is that it is up against the jungle background setting and has a nice layout of many buildings.  Some of these buildings have nice detail.  In the background you can hear howler monkeys (although I did not see any.), and see other wildlife.  It truely is a picture perfect ruin to visit.  Take a look at the photos I submitted to get a feel for it.

I agree with the previous reviews of Palenque in their content and on the recommendations of the guides.  The guides give your very basic information which you can find out ahead of time by reading the basics before visiting the ruins, and they do not take you to any special areas that you cannot visit on your own.

Negatives:

The only negative thing I can say is that the Mexican government charges tourist at every opportunity.  First, upon entering the "jungle/wildlife zone".  Second, admission to the park.  And third, for a permit to use a video camera.  While the charges are not huge, they are annoying.  And since I visited the park on two different days, I got to pay each of these charges all over again!

Helpful Hints:

1.  If you stay in the city, you can take a mini van to the ruins by standing on the road to the ruins and looking like a tourist.  They will stop ask if you want a ride to the ruins, and charge you around 10 pesos (price 2 years ago.) to go to the ruins.
2.  In route to the park the mini bus will stop for the guards that are"protecting"(aka toll booth) the park.  You will have to pay a fee to enter the protected area (aka tourist tax - others in the minibus from Mexico, or appeared to be from Mexico were not approached to pay the fee.).  Go ahead and pay it, but MAKE SURE that your receipt has the correct date stamped, or you might get charged again.  I was given a ticket they stamped in advance from the day before.  So especially if you arrive early, make sure that you ticket has the correct date and is not a leftover stamped from the day before.
3.  Arrive early.  You can see the entire park in one day, but it will be a full day.
4.  Take a lunch break and go visit the museum.  Two reasons. First to cool off.  Second to visit the office and to ask special permission to enter one of the temples that was excavated.  Near the end of the day at a very specific time you can climb down the long staircase and visit the tomb inside for 15-20 minutes.  This is worth doing.  In order to get permisson, you will have to write a letter requesting so at the museum office.  Once you do this, they will give a limited number of tickets out to the first that come.  So take an early lunch to do this.  Be advised that this option is only on certain days, so ask in advance.
5.  Make sure that your hotel has AC.  In Palenque it is very hot and humid.  It is very refreshing at the end of the day to come back to a cool hotel room.

I hope that this added information helps you in your visit of Palenque.  Please take the time to rate my review below.  Thank you.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

11883794.name: Enchanting
11883794.author: a TripAdvisor user
11883794.reviewBody: The ruins of Palenque are located in the jungle and this unique l set up enhances the mystery of Palenque. It is difficult to describe Palenque as words cannot capture the majestic atmosphere. Standing on top of the highest building looking at the beautiful mixture of the Mayan architecture raising from the jungle is an unforgettable experience. If you have the time  - you can go deep into the Jungle and learn more about the Mayans culture and its linkage to nature. A word of recommendation - hire a good guide! It is almost impossible to understand the site without one.

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

4591734.name: Avoid the Guides
4591734.author: a TripAdvisor user
4591734.reviewBody: The site of Palenque is stunning.  The setting is much more breath-taking than that of Chichen Itza or Uxmal or the other Yucatan sites.  It is definitely worth a visit.  My recommendation, though, is to stay away from the guides.  While the guides at Chichen Itza were incredibly helpful, my guide at Palenque told me such things like: the Mayans were wiped out by a meteorite collision that formed the Gulf of Mexico, the Mayans were in contact with Asia and India, and that the Mayans were advanced metalworkers.  All demonstrably untrue and counter to current archaeological opinion.  The guide added no value so avoid at all costs no matter how much they pester you.\n

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

4389646.name: Ruins in the forest
4389646.author: a TripAdvisor user
4389646.reviewBody: Palenque is worth the effort it takes to reach it. Many of the buildings are well preserved or restored and the art in the temples is fantastic. The city was built where hills begin to rise from the plain, so many of the temples back up against hillsides covered with forest. The grounds of the ruins are well-kept, giving the feel of a park.\n

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

3433111.name: Better than Chichen-Itza
3433111.author: a TripAdvisor user
3433111.reviewBody: Chichen-Itza gets all the attention. That\'s too bad because Palenque has the more notable Mayan ruins beat hands-down. Set in the rainforest in Chiapas, it\'s positively magical in the morning when the fog lifts over the ruins. The main ruins have been restored, but if you walk up the trails away from the crowds, you can see some astounding half-excavated ruins, too, with trees entangled in the stones as in Cambodia\'s famous Tah Prom. Take the time to climb the stairs, as many as you can bear, to get the full experience. Sadly, there\'s not a lot of options for lodging or food in Palenque--at least not yet. Hotel Chan Kah Ruinas is likely the best of a not-so-great bunch of options. Despite that, it\'s worth the stay to experience the morning.\n

address.streetAddress: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8

675318419.name: My favorite of the dozen major Mayan sites we visited
675318419.author: a TripAdvisor user
675318419.reviewBody: Palenque seemed somehow better planned and organized that other sites. The various buildings seemed "properly" related to one another. It all made sense.  Or maybe I\'m just putting a personal spin. Lots of opportunities to climb on the buildings, with good perspectives from the various perches at the top. If I had to pick only one site to visit, this would be it.\n\nThere are lots of five star Mayan sites, but some five star sites are more equal than others. That would be Palenque.

675099025.name: Amazing Place\ud83d\ude0d\u2764
675099025.author: a TripAdvisor user
675099025.reviewBody: This place is absolutely stunning. Amazing for meditation close to the observatory, great views to the ruins, beautiful flora and fauna. Home of the Saraguato monkey, Jaguars and exotic birds. It is really beautiful.

672637845.name: Amazing place
672637845.author: a TripAdvisor user
672637845.reviewBody: Beautiful place, very well preserved, and not as expensive as others (also because we didn\'t request any guide) Totally worth it!

670204950.name: interesting site
670204950.author: a TripAdvisor user
670204950.reviewBody: nice place to visit, we had a guide for about an hour, then we paid extra for another hour to see the ruins actually in the jungle that had not been fully excavated.  It was good but a little rushed.  Then the guy gave us an hour back at the ruins for time to take photos.\nWe had paid for the ruins visit in with our holiday, but the guide offered the extra trip into the jungle.  Just be aware that they have a board up with 1300 pesos pp or 95 us dollars.  We said it was too much so he asked us what we wanted to pay, I would have said 500 peso\'s but my husband said 800 pesos per person which he agreed on.

670194560.name: Spectacular Maya ruins
670194560.author: a TripAdvisor user
670194560.reviewBody: We\'ve contracted a guide to walk us around the complex and a part of the nature. This was absolutely worth the money spend. The complex is compact and has some really exceptional places. When you are in the surroundings of Palenque, this is a must see !

668983770.name: Great visit
668983770.author: a TripAdvisor user
668983770.reviewBody: Nice place to learn maya history! I would recommend it as good place to learn and admire this culture!!

668965235.name: Interesting site Palenque
668965235.author: a TripAdvisor user
668965235.reviewBody: Visited Palenque at the end of March, it was pretty hot that day (38 degrees). Interesting site in it\'s own style.

668926901.name: Ancient city in rainforest jungle
668926901.author: a TripAdvisor user
668926901.reviewBody:
My wife and I went to Mexico for our honeymoon and during our time there, we explored many of the Mesoamerican sites. 

Each site is different. The style, architecture, art work, climate, everything is unique to each site. 

Palenque is what we now think of as the 'rainforest jungle ruins'. 

The air is hot and humid. The bugs love it. To be honest though, apart from them, so did we. 
Upon arrival (after we paid parking, entrance fee etc) we were approached by a local tour guide (A few of the Mesoamerican sites have tour guides available by the entrance) who showed us a map of the area and explained that the majority of the ancient city is still in the jungle which is now protected. Only a small percentage has been excavated and, to some degree, restored/ rebuilt. He offered to take us on a two hour walk in the jungle to see the ruins as they were when archaeologists came to excavate them. Too intriguing to resist, off we went with Marco into the jungle. 

It involved some climbing, some crawl scuttling through a mostly buried 'house', some swinging on vines (because I'm like that!), hopping from stone to stone in a shallow river, we saw howler monkeys, various types of bird and plant life, a few ancient buildings buried amongst the trees... It was brilliant. Well worth the unexpected extra expense. (I think it cost us about £60) 

It made exploring the excavated ruins that much more impressive. We had an extra layer of appreciation. Firstly the way they were originally built but then, all those years later, the people that found them in the jungle and then excavated and lovingly rebuilt them. Just incredible. One of the main archaeologists that worked on the site is actually laid to rest there too, you can see his tomb opposite the main structures in the site. 

Palenque is another fantastic place for any history lover to visit. It has the additional benefit of being good for nature lovers too. 

We recommend you bring lots to drink, a hat, sun cream and plenty of bug repellent.

666828805.name: Amazing
666828805.author: a TripAdvisor user
666828805.reviewBody: It\'s a wonderful place to visit. Very well kept and clean. If you go, I recommend you to take the long trail down to the museum where you will find the most amazing Pakal sarcophagus replica and where all you saw at the site will make sense.

666435814.name: UNBELIEVABLE!
666435814.author: a TripAdvisor user
666435814.reviewBody: I recently visited this site on a GateOne tour of the Yucatan.  I had studied the history of this site for some time, but seeing it in the \'flesh\' still took my breath away.\nI highly recommend the climb up the steps to the Red Queen\'s tomb.\nOur guide was EXCELLENT - Francisco Anaya - a GEM!!

666096163.name: Must see when in Palenque.
666096163.author: a TripAdvisor user
666096163.reviewBody: Spent many hours just wandering and looking around at this incredible site. It\'s not empty of tourists, but it\'s not Chichen Itza either. Just take your time and soak it all in and you will be rewarded.

663655683.name: Best for exploring!
663655683.author: a TripAdvisor user
663655683.reviewBody: We took the ADO from Merida to Palenque, it\u2019s a 10 hour journey but we were assured that it would be worth the trip.\nWe were not disappointed! We arrived on a cool, damp day, which added to the atmosphere of the ruins. Because the jungle is protected they will not excavate any further, so take a guided tour through the jungle to see ruins you might otherwise miss. We got taken through an underground aquaduct and saw bats and spiders. The plants of the jungle were explained to us and we were passed by Mayan villagers on horseback who still live in the area.\nThe excavated ruins are spectacular; set against the backdrop of the jungle. We\u2019d already been to a number of Mayan ruins, including Chichen Itza, and it really did strike us just how different each one is. Here you can see the stone beds inside the buildings, and the stones used for sacrifices.

662480330.name: Magical Maya History
662480330.author: a TripAdvisor user
662480330.reviewBody: The Classic Maya Culture reaches its zenith at Palenque in the 7th century AD.  The citizens of Palenque created an artistic and architectural marvel in a jungle locale of breathtaking beauty.  To visit the ruins at Palenque is to time travel back over a thousand years and wonder at these people who somehow built temples and pyramids without knowledge of the wheel.  When you visit, make certain you save two hours for the small but excellent museum on site, where you find a complete and informative exhibition about the sarcophagus of King Pacal found inside the Temple of the Inscriptions in the 1950s.

660429111.name: Plenty of undiscovered parts
660429111.author: a TripAdvisor user
660429111.reviewBody: First off, this is one to do with a guide as there are vast amounts of the complex still to be excavated.  Its a fair walk round to cover everything and get all the views.  It is a decent place to get a good view of some Mayan history and look at some interesting temples.  There is a little museum that has some nice pieces.  Its somewhere if you go to Palenque you will go here as there isn\'t much else.  I think this place needs to upgrade some of its general facilities at the moment and try and organise the sellers a bit better though.

660239962.name: Lovely grounds
660239962.author: a TripAdvisor user
660239962.reviewBody: The ruins are enjoyable to see and contemplate. The site is gorgeous and there are beautiful trees and jungle plants. There are plenty of food and drink vendors outside the main area.

660009117.name: Breathtaking
660009117.author: a TripAdvisor user
660009117.reviewBody: The combination of setting, spaciousness, solitude and history is unprecedented in my experience - and all so accessible.  We found the site to be a treasure trove.  Allmost too good to be true.  The Palenque site is not just a place to visit in passing, it is a destination in its own right, and an unmissable one.

659704326.name: Amazing!
659704326.author: a TripAdvisor user
659704326.reviewBody: I am coming close to understanding how Mayan civilization worked. It only took Tikal, all the places in the Yucatan and finally Palenque which is simply great. It is nice to be able (both because it is allowed and because am getting so old) to climb so many of the pyramids and see so many well preserved stucco works. The genius of Mayan architecture comes through here, although I would not have liked being a peasant in these parts in those times.

659529614.name: Must see
659529614.author: a TripAdvisor user
659529614.reviewBody: This is a must see if you are in the Palenque area. Make sure you use Mosquito spray. Only place we really needed it

658532911.name: Best
658532911.author: a TripAdvisor user
658532911.reviewBody: Of all the archaeological sites I\'ve visited in Mexico and Central America, Palenque remains my favorite. It\'s the ever-encroaching jungle, vendors who respect tradition, and my favorite part - the walk down to the museum, with waterfalls and trees to rival the Redwoods. Excellent signage.

658520086.name: Maya magic
658520086.author: a TripAdvisor user
658520086.reviewBody: Superb archaelogical site, not overcrowded reflecting its relatively remote location. Well worth taking a good guide to help with interpretation. Not so many steps to challenge you here as the Temple of the Inscriptions can\'t be climbed. But in the heat, there is no substitute for a hat and plenty of water. Don\'t miss the small museum....some wonderful artefacts on display.

658028778.name: Wonderful site & setting.
658028778.author: a TripAdvisor user
658028778.reviewBody: Go early as it gets hot. Well preserved & maintained the site is quite spectacular. The path from the main temples/buildings to the museum is a nice wander through jungle beside a lovely stream. Museum is worth a visit too. Watch for the scammer guide who will point out piles of vine covered rubble for only $195USD. There are authentic cheaper ones. We were happy with self guiding & reading the signs.

657080508.name: Explore the jungle ruins!
657080508.author: a TripAdvisor user
657080508.reviewBody: Going early really paid off. U avoid the heat, groups of tourists and also local sellers that sometimes ruin your pictures as they spread all over the site. We took colectivo at 8am for 20 pesos and asked to be dropped off at the museum. There was nobody. 30min at the museum and then we walked up from this end to the ruins. Usually most tourists start from a different entrance and exit at this museum or at the same gate where they started. We decided to first see the museum and read stuff about the site (which was quite helpful) and from there take the path up. It takes around 15 to 20 min, depending on how many pictures you are taking, but the path is beautiful. The whole ruins are stunning. U can end your tour at the other gate where most tourists start and take colectivo back to palenque. They go often. You won\'t miss anything this way. U can use offline maps.me, they are accurate with showing paths and tempes, but the museum is really recommended before u enter, unless you wanna pay a guide.  No tripods allowed inside, no drones.

657064316.name: Amazing ruins and histiry
657064316.author: a TripAdvisor user
657064316.reviewBody: Stunning ruins set in the jungle. Makes you feel like Indiana Jones! The museum is also worth a visit to see some of the artefacts from the site. Go with a guide to get the full experience and all the historical facts.

656426574.name: Majestic and quiet
656426574.author: a TripAdvisor user
656426574.reviewBody: We and the tour buses and vendors got there at 9:00 when it opened.  The bus crowd rushed through and they and the vendors were gone by 11:00, after which we virtually had it to ourselves.  It\'s a magnificent, and majestic, experience.

655827978.name: An incredible insight to Mayan history
655827978.author: a TripAdvisor user
655827978.reviewBody: There are ruins and then there are Ruins! Palenque\'s epic Mayan ruins are the latter. Set amid lush, green jungle this epic site takes a good few hours to properly explore (best done in the morning when it\'s cooler and the crowds are thinner). Guiding services are pretty hefty price wise (we were quoted about 1000 pesos) and honestly if you do your research before going and download a map of the park (the lonely planet has a good one) then you don\'t need a guide at all. They\'ll warn you the park\'s big enough to get lost in without their expensive guidance but while it\'s big you won\'t get lost! You will however burn your thighs and calves climbing some of the bigger temples!

653232696.name: Well known site not too busy
653232696.author: a TripAdvisor user
653232696.reviewBody: Worth every minute to visit this 1987 World Heritage Site.  It does not get too crowded early in the day

652428019.name: Beautiful site!
652428019.author: a TripAdvisor user
652428019.reviewBody:
We spent the day at the archeological site today. We drove from our hotel and we were guided to one of the only parking places available. You purchase an arm band at the first entrance, then tickets before entering the park. The tickets also give you access to the museum. 

We were hoping there might be a group tour, but ended up hiring a guide named Victor for $1,000 pesos (much less than the $95 US suggested on the board).

Victor spoke good English and had a great tour. He had articles and photos and other books he referenced to teach us about the site. The great thing about using a guide is that they help you see so many things about the architecture, glyphs, reliefs, paintings and more that you would miss on your own. He told us about the family that ruled, the classical period in Maya history, various explorers who came to the area and so much more. 

He obviously had a great appreciation for the site and kept asking us to imagine it in its original color, white stucco and bright paintings against the green of the jungle. 

An added bonus was listening to the Howler monkeys - wow, they are loud!  There are lots of souvenir-sellers around the parking area and a few on the grounds, but they are not aggressive. 

We really enjoyed the day!

652205472.name: Climb to the top of the Temple of the Cross for the best views!
652205472.author: a TripAdvisor user
652205472.reviewBody:
Excellent ruins made even more interesting and beautiful since they're part of the jungle landscape.
We hired a guide in Spanish (we are fluent speakers) who first quoted us the price of the ruins and jungle tour for 1,500 MXN....we walked away to discuss the price (too high for us) and then with more negotiation he brought it down to $800 MXN.  In the meantime, we were approached by other guides with other prices...
There are a lot of guides that will pounce on you the minute you arrive.  Make sure to talk to a few and get prices, but also go with the one who you feel comfortable with...some are very pushy but others give you some space.

I highly recommend you do the jungle tour...you will walk on top of pyramids and temples that are still covered in jungle trees and plants just as the ruins you see once were...it was fascinating.  Plus guides can point out fruits you can try, or even insects...if you're game.  ;)  If you're lucky, you'll see some howler monkeys like we did.
Bring sunscreen, a hat, water and comfortable shoes.  Before you hire a guide, tell them you want to take the tour at a slow pace so that you can really enjoy the landscape, take photos and just sit and observe the space.  Some guides want to rush, and you shouldn't feel rushed when you take in these remarkable ruins.

651472114.name: Impressive and atmospheric Mayan ruins
651472114.author: a TripAdvisor user
651472114.reviewBody: The archeological site of ancient Mayan city of Palenque is definitely worth a visit. The site in nested in a jungle giving it almost mystical, adventurous feeling (like you are in Indiana Jones movie). We came at 9h and visited the museum where we got some more information helping us better understand what we were about to see. We entered through a lower eco-path and it was just great walking up along side water and grass-covered ruins and then coming up to the plane where, before your eyes, the exquisite city of Pacal the Great unfolds. The atmosphere of the place, it\u2019s history, the monumental structures, the fact that it was absorbed by jungle and then rediscovered.. all this and more comes together in making this cite unique, mystical and impressive.

651096269.name: Hot!
651096269.author: a TripAdvisor user
651096269.reviewBody:
It has an amazing view, the architecture, how it was built, the history.
Its amazing the things we have in America and we go to Europe to see things we can see here.

Must go place but bring lots of water

650172815.name: Amazing Mayan site
650172815.author: a TripAdvisor user
650172815.reviewBody: We visited 8 Mayan sites during a recent trip to Mexico - this was one of the best/most interesting/better preserved-restored and somewhat less overwhelmingly touristy than say Chechen Itza

649008136.name: Amazing ancient history nestled in the jungle.
649008136.author: a TripAdvisor user
649008136.reviewBody: Such a beautiful place with a variety of ruins. From temples to residential areas, jungle hikes, and beautiful waterfalls.. this place has it all. Even the local indigenous people sell amazing art throughout the archeological site. We came back 2 days in a row, as the site is so large its hard to fully explore in one day. Very affordable, and worth the price as the money goes to maintaining the site. So so epic!

647686371.name: Palenque: An ancient Maya treasure.
647686371.author: a TripAdvisor user
647686371.reviewBody:
I travelled all day by bus and was weary and tired when I arrived that night in Palenque. It did not diminish my excitement because I knew this would be one of the highlights of my Mexican discovery trip. I slept well and was ready to explore at the crack of dawn.
Having been a part of a jungle tour before arriving at Palenque, it gave me a broader perspective of this vast site. As I entered this site as a part of an Intrepid Tour group, it is breathtaking as I viewed these incredible looking ancient buildings. The Temple of Inscriptions and the Palace is a daunting presence as it soars way beyond the vegetation in the background.
Palenque is an archaeological site, that is mysterious, solemn, well preserved and imposing. One has to navigate off the beaten track, since Palenque is nestled in a steamy and luscious jungle setting, rising majestically from the green grassy hills and shrouded in early morning mist. Since I was surrounded by thick jungle, it was the perfect backdrop for the Maya people who settled here in 100BC
We were fortunate to have Victor as our guide who was an expert on the Maya culture and guided us for three hours, and thereafter, I explored the site until late afternoon. He informed us that the great ruler Pakal was entombed in the Temple of Inscriptions, which is off-limits to all visitors.
It is a large area with courtyards, an observatory and other smaller attachments. We learnt that the findings of the Maya culture were continually changing as new inscriptions are been deciphered. At times they were a warrior people, then a kingdom of peace, and were also people of high intellectual level and produced great mathematicians and astronomers. Everything I witnessed was constructed without metal tools, pack animals or the wheel, and my mind reminisced the times when these structures were in its infancy many centuries ago. Palenque would have been majestic looking and would have taken our breath away. 
As I wandered around this huge arena by myself, viewing these imposing structures of Palenque, with hidden chambers, the unique water channels, inscriptions and reliefs, it made me feel so privileged and I did have enormous respect for the Maya civilisation. The unique architecture of its buildings that were constructed in the middle of this mysterious thick jungle is a testament to their superior knowledge as great builders. I remember our guide explaining about the demise of Palenque when the lower classes rebelled and did not have faith in the Gods and rulers of this kingdom. After a long period of internal warfare, it fell into steep decline, and the inhabitants deserted the city and temples, and the ever-encroaching jungle abandoned the buildings.
Tips and recommendations: Before arriving at the main site, it is recommended to book the jungle tour, approximately US 15.00. The jungle tour involved walking around enormous tropical trees, as we crisscrossed rivers and wooden bridges while passing old Maya ruins. We also crept through hidden caves where the terrain was quite treacherous since it was wet and slippery. Many undiscovered temples and palaces are hidden from view, and this did whet our appetite for the excitement that lay ahead. Once we emerged onto the main Palenque site, it did heighten our appreciation of the mysterious dark rainforest that hid many Maya secrets still to be discovered. Since I arrived on a Monday, the Museum was closed, and this was a big disappointment for me. From all the reviews that were submitted, this is a gem.

647683879.name: Nice
647683879.author: a TripAdvisor user
647683879.reviewBody: Well, this is not the most impressive thing I have seen, but it is nice.\nThe walk itself between ruins is kind of good experience especially when the weather is sunny.\nIt is good to take with you a map *or in other way buy it at the entrance.

647245949.name: Amazing & Beautiful
647245949.author: a TripAdvisor user
647245949.reviewBody:
Located in mountain foothills and with abundant surface water, the ancient Mayan city of Palenque is quite different than any other we explored.  

There are a huge number of structures--some essentially rubble and others in excellent condition--throughout the large area.  Supposedly many others--both known and undiscovered--are still covered by the tropical jungle.

You are free to climb in, on and into many of the structures.  Be careful on the perpetually shaded, modern and rather crude steps along lesser visited paths.  I twisted my ankle slightly on the way down one such and missed the visit into the do-not-miss "palace" as any sort of misstep on the extremely steep stairs is certain to cause severe pain if not death ;)

Like the other historic sites we visited in the Mayan region it's very easy to self-guide without missing anything of importance. Also like other sites in the region it is apparent that the commercial tours are abbreviated.  Following the "exit" signs at Palenque leads you down a fabulous trail through the jungle!

Anything less than 3-4 hours on site and you cannot truly appreciate!

646170582.name: Beautifully situated ruins
646170582.author: a TripAdvisor user
646170582.reviewBody: While the Palenque ruins aren\'t the most impressive ruins in Mexico (Teotihuacan and Chichen Itza are much bigger), they\'re certainly in the most beautiful location, as they\'re completely surrounded by jungle. Take a colectivo here from the town of Palenque. Also, don\'t forget the small museum at the end if you\'re interested in Mayan and Palenque history :-)

645862027.name: Fun day trip, but can get busy!
645862027.author: a TripAdvisor user
645862027.reviewBody: We visited the ruins on the 31st December, so it was quite busy! However, it was well worth it. We spent a day at the ruins and it was beautiful. There are so many sites to climb and explore. Be prepared for the heat! You will be climbing stairs with little shade around. Once you\'ve explored all the ruins sites, take the 30 min trail through to the museum - there is a beautiful bridge and waterfall to discover on the way. I would also recommend the coconut at the entrance of the ruins! It was the best we had on the trip.

645398086.name: Awesome
645398086.author: a TripAdvisor user
645398086.reviewBody: We spent 2 days around the ruins. The setup is amazing and the jungle around makes it even more atmospheric, despite the vendors of various artifacts? We took a 15 hour bus there ...well worth it though.

645386843.name: Great site, but get there early
645386843.author: a TripAdvisor user
645386843.reviewBody: This is a fantastic site in a jungle setting. Unfortunately, a visit could easily be ruined by the excessive number of hawkers and the appalling behaviour of some of the tourists. If you have the time, visit over 2 days, once through the main entrance for the upper part of the site, and once through the small lower entrance. Get there at 8am, when it opens, and you\'ll be able to see a good chunk of it before it\'s flooded with hawkers and coach trips.

643735746.name: Nice setting in the jungle
643735746.author: a TripAdvisor user
643735746.reviewBody:
These ruins have a nice setting in the jungle and are well restored.  The grounds are also well kept, with the grass and trees providing a nice relief from the heat.  Sign boards are in good condition and helpful, but get a guide as the information they give has a lot more life to it.
The museum is also nice to go and see, there's a nice path through the jungle from the ruins to the museum.
The stall holders turn the area into a bit of a market, but they don't hassle you too much and it's easy enough to ignore them if you don't want anything.
If you do though, apparently they're cheaper here than in town.

643346261.name: Very impressive
643346261.author: a TripAdvisor user
643346261.reviewBody:
Having come from Tikal in Guatemala, we were excited to see these ruins. 

There is no denying how impressive they are and so well restored however the site is ruined by tourists climbing all over them. This is not only irritating for taking pictures but will destroy these temples, palaces etc. - this will one day be banned like it has in Cambodia. 

Another annoyance is the vast amount of street hawkers lining all the paths, making animal noises constantly. 

It is definitely somewhere to visit and there is plenty of information available in English around the site and in the museum.

643152763.name: Palenque
643152763.author: a TripAdvisor user
643152763.reviewBody: Beautiful and exciting place to know more about the Mayas and they\u2019re great knowledge about time and mathematics.

642742083.name: Great ruins but don\'t go on Monday
642742083.author: a TripAdvisor user
642742083.reviewBody: Amazing ruins. They\'re very spread out so be prepared for a lot of walking. Unfortunately the site museum is closed on Mondays which was disappointing as museum entrance is included in the ruin entrance fee. We would have gone on a different day if I knew this.

641692030.name: Mayan ruins
641692030.author: a TripAdvisor user
641692030.reviewBody:
Beautiful place! Mayan palaces mostly on plain surface.
Can climb the pyramids.
Not much place to sit 
Is accessible for elderly people with walking difficulties but only on ground level ( not climbing the pyramids), only few steps to see the main palace. 
You can buy suvinirs on ground but no food in the park. The is food and beverage out side the Park.
Price is quite cheap.
Take water with you because it tends to get hot. Also sunblock.

641564287.name: A must see in chiapas
641564287.author: a TripAdvisor user
641564287.reviewBody:
We were family of 6 (children ages 16, 13, 11,8)
We took a guide and it worth any peso. The place is amazing (and huge). The guide (dolfino) explain with patience and with photos and maps. The kids where enthusiastic to hear more.
Totally 1.5 hours of guided tour and another hour that we self walked in the other tamples in the site

640930650.name: A marketplace in the middle of the jungle
640930650.author: a TripAdvisor user
640930650.reviewBody:
We went with very high expectations for the place itself and if we would take into account the ruins themselves and the history of the place, this would make it one of the most amazing places I've seen in my life.

On the other hand I can understand local people are trying to make a living by any means possible, but I can not understand that someone somewhere allows these people to turn such an important cultural place into a common open air market. In the park itself there is a possibility to buy anything, from souvenirs made in China to tacos.

Would I recommend this place? Of course. Is it a shame the authorities allow the sales of everything on the ruins themselves? Yes it is and ruins the experience for anyone visiting

Normally: 5 stars
With the market included: terrible

640862197.name: Wow, huge place, so cool
640862197.author: a TripAdvisor user
640862197.reviewBody:
My husband and I went to Mexico for our anniversary earlier this year. One of the places we visited was Palenque. It is huge and so cool. It is sort of hassle to enter, with lots of check points. Also guides trying to sell their services (and not cheap) though they are typically worth it if they are licensed.

There were a lot of vendors by the entrance as well, selling clothes and food. Even in the parking lot there were people wanting money to "watch you car" for you. It was a little outrageous.

Inside there were also some vendors selling things, but not as bad as some other ruins we've been to in Mexico.

There were quite a few signs around the grounds to give us information about what we were seeing. There were benches in the shade to sit on, as there is a fair amount of walking. However there were no restrooms that we could find once you went through the entrance.

The temples are huge and there are so many buildings in the complex. There were a lot of very pretty plants growing on the grounds too. This is such an interesting part of the history of Mexico and totally worth the visit.

640579860.name: A worthwhile Mayan site to visit
640579860.author: a TripAdvisor user
640579860.reviewBody: This is well preserved example of a Mayan centre with lots of details to investigate. It is reasonably compact, so you don\'t have to walk excessively to see it all.\nIt is in an area of jungle, so quite a pretty situation.

640437246.name: Would pay any amount of money
640437246.author: a TripAdvisor user
640437246.reviewBody: This is a must do if your in Mexico not just palenque it\'s absolutely fascinating I could be here all day describing how amazing it is.

640201013.name: Historic place
640201013.author: a TripAdvisor user
640201013.reviewBody: This is an amazing place that shows how prehispanic people from Mayan culture use tu live.\nNice place in the middle of the jungle that you must visit in Chiapas.

638984798.name: Palenque, wow
638984798.author: a TripAdvisor user
638984798.reviewBody: This is probably one of the most beautiful ruins in Mexico. The Palenque ruins are set in the jungle. The ruins are very, very impressive. There are many stairs and hills to climb. You can climb the ruins. Very, very nice, ginving you some fantastic views ovr the jungle. \n\nSo, use anti-musqito-spray or you get eaten by bugs.

638952244.name: My favourite ruins in Mexico
638952244.author: a TripAdvisor user
638952244.reviewBody: I\'ve been traveling in Mexico for a month and Palenque has been my favourite ruins\' spot. I visited this area with a guide for two hours and it has been a great choice: ruins and taste of the jungle, totally recommend it

638867446.name: If  you have to see juste one...this is the one!
638867446.author: a TripAdvisor user
638867446.reviewBody: If like me you had a picture in your mind of what ancient ruins should look like, well this one is has close has it gets to my childood dreams. Take the time to look around and if available get a gided tour with an actual archeologiste.

638554527.name: A stunning setting
638554527.author: a TripAdvisor user
638554527.reviewBody: This temple complex is situated close to the jungle with hills to one side. In the earlier part of the day this makes it quite atmospheric with mist circling the hills and trees. Most of the complex is accessible but there is some work going on. The buildings are very impressive.

638236540.name: Outstanding ruins!
638236540.author: a TripAdvisor user
638236540.reviewBody: Although not the easiest to get to, Palenque is one of the most amazing of the Mayan ruins.  The site is expansive and if you get there at opening you can enjoy the site before the tour groups descend.  Even with those groups the site does not feel crowded,  Most of the structures are open to climbing and from the top you can get a great view of the encroaching jungle.  Sit awhile and take in the history.

636775313.name: Great ruins.
636775313.author: a TripAdvisor user
636775313.reviewBody: After a walk through the nearby jungle where you can see lots of ruins waiting to be restored it was wonderful to walk into this site . beautifully restored, wonderful stories and very few tourists.

636768424.name: Fascinating ruins in a jungle area
636768424.author: a TripAdvisor user
636768424.reviewBody: We had already visited several Mesoamerican ruins but still found enough differences for these to retain our interest. A good local guide certainly enhanced our visit. The surrounding jungle offered a different outlook to more northern sites on higher more barren ground. We enjoyed the fact that we started from the upper entrance near the main attractions but left through the jungle path down the streams and waterfalls   past uncleared ruins of lesser buildings to arrive opposite the site museum.

635070495.name: One Of The Best Ruins To See
635070495.author: a TripAdvisor user
635070495.reviewBody: Really a great spot. Way more interactive than Chich\u00e9n Itz\u00e1. You can climb on most of the structures. Not too crowded either. Great for a morning photo shoot. There were vendors there, but they were not annoying, and all were friendly with directions. A fantastic experience.

634224727.name: Fabulous! Do not miss!!!
634224727.author: a TripAdvisor user
634224727.reviewBody: Palenque is one of the four Mayan ceremonial cities and be sure to leave enough time to visit it thoroughly. You can rent a guide at the entrance.   After visiting the main temples, you can do the eco-walk (takes about 45 minutes) which ends at the site museum.   If you don\'t want to walk there is a shuttle to the museum.\n\nLet  me mention the State of Chiapas store (close to the ladies room) in the building next to the museum. Prices are VERY reasonable - especially for items set in silver (925.sterling).   These were the best prices I saw anywhere for these items.

634006055.name: A Day in the ruins
634006055.author: a TripAdvisor user
634006055.reviewBody:
The archeological ruins of Palenque are the remains of one of the Mayan people’s most important cities.
Surrounded by thick, lush vegetation, the ruins are a great place for visitors to hike through and practice bird watching.
I had a wonderful day in the Maya Ruins, I learned a lot, the environment filled me with good vibes, something I needed for a long time, I loved what was sold there, the necklaces, the stones, definitely love Mexico I would stay there forever. 
The past that Mexico has is something to admire and its architecture something worthy to appress.

632660664.name: Buen\u00edsimo
632660664.author: a TripAdvisor user
632660664.reviewBody: Incredible Mayan City, many temples, very well kept, an amazing visit, a great learning experience\nYou must come

631781421.name: Stunning!
631781421.author: a TripAdvisor user
631781421.reviewBody: Loved every single temple & stone! Really take your time to do the full tour and to really take it all in!\nPark also has great signs in English. Combined with a travel book, it will give you a lot of information - so up to you to do an extra guided tour, but no must.

631747061.name: Amazing mayan monument, a must see
631747061.author: a TripAdvisor user
631747061.reviewBody: If you are into history of Maya, this should be on your list. The location might be more remote compared to Chichen Itza and Uxmal but it\u2019s worth the visit. Read guide or history book before visit so you can really appreciate how important this place used to be. The ruin is in the jungle area but don\u2019t worry about mosquitos or bugs. I didn\u2019t get any single bite during 2 hour visit. Try to come early to avoid the crowd and the heat. It could unbearable.

631278282.name: Fantastic ruins
631278282.author: a TripAdvisor user
631278282.reviewBody: Great location, stunning scenery, very good museum. Get there early to avoid crowds. Only downside is the number of souvenir people sitting all around the ruins.

631061197.name: Palenque will amaze you!
631061197.author: a TripAdvisor user
631061197.reviewBody: The Mayan culture and society was highly developed. This is a place where you will be able to see this society\u2019s splendor!

630189468.name: Incredible Ruins
630189468.author: a TripAdvisor user
630189468.reviewBody: This was a delight from the start. Your in the jungle now. These Ruins, slowly being uncovered and reconstructed. Incredible story of Pakal and the world of the Maya rule. The Palace is magnificent.

629003450.name: Perfect
629003450.author: a TripAdvisor user
629003450.reviewBody:
Give yourself a whole day for this. It is amazing, jaw droppingly good.

Wish the jaguar whistles the hawkers sound off all the time were banned. 

Take decent walking boots. Enjoy!

627806011.name: Earnesto the guide.
627806011.author: a TripAdvisor user
627806011.reviewBody: The ruins are great with something different from other sites,  guides are expensive but keep refusing until the price drops rapidly and ours was Earnesto who really gave us a great insight into the culture.

625623739.name: Nice visit
625623739.author: a TripAdvisor user
625623739.reviewBody:
We made 2 payments: 34 and 70 pesos per person. 

A lot os souvenirs shops outside and inside the ruins. 

Easy to arrive with "colectivo" (small bus) paying 20 pesos per person to go and another 20 to go back to palenque center. 

We visited in October and the ruins were almost empty. There was maintenance all over the place so you could see construction workers everywhere. 

The ruins are in very good shape and you can climb almost all the monuments. 

Worth the visit!

624940425.name: More Impressive than Chichen Itza
624940425.author: a TripAdvisor user
624940425.reviewBody: These jungle set ruins are superb. They don\u2019t have as many tourists as Chichen Itza, don\u2019t have 100s of vendors hassling you and you can walk on the ruins. The main pyramid provides great views of the site and the jungle beyond. Great insight on why the Mayan civilisation failed from a local guide. Well worth a visit

624824228.name: Came back in the Maya\'s age
624824228.author: a TripAdvisor user
624824228.reviewBody: One of the best experience of my life... we walk trough all this ruins... only the 10% is been discover yet but they\'re stunning. The all Chiapas is a gorgeous region to visit. Agua azul and San Cristobal also worth a stop.

622913202.name: Most beautiful ruins in Mexico
622913202.author: a TripAdvisor user
622913202.reviewBody: You should take some time and discover also the ruins in the jungle around the area. Very nice. For me until now the most beautiful ruins in Mexico so far.

622253864.name: Gorgeous and different from the other ruins
622253864.author: a TripAdvisor user
622253864.reviewBody: These ruins truely speak to the imagination. Only 5% uncovered. Very beautiful builings that are nicely restorated. The usage of plaster to cover the walls instead of cut stones was very unique. The palace, most tempels and the tombe are stil open for visitors.

622006472.name: Palenque, a jawdropping Mayan city ruins !
622006472.author: a TripAdvisor user
622006472.reviewBody: Palenque is a journey into the history and mysticism of the Mayan Culture. It\'s one of the top destinations of Chiapas region. We spent a whole day exploring the site which spreads over 15 sq km, but it was not enough, so we went back the next day. It is better to start the trip early to enjoy the serenity of the ruins before other visitors start coming in and because Palenque gets hot and humid around noon (but who cares really when you can experience the sound, smell, and the out-of-this-world-feeling of being inside the jungle !). By the way, we stayed at Hotel Cabana Safari, an amazing place in the middle of the jungle, located at only 8 km from the Palenque Archaeologican Zone. Palenque is one of the best experience we\'ve had, with Chichen Itza. Palenque is a must for lovers of intense emotions !

621369300.name: Awesome site.
621369300.author: a TripAdvisor user
621369300.reviewBody: Truly a must see. The Mayans were magnificent builders and Palenque is one of the most impressive sites I have see so far.

620582857.name: Gem
620582857.author: a TripAdvisor user
620582857.reviewBody: One of the reason I travel to this region.... This is above chichen itza... Way better, grander and more peacefull....

619498435.name: Absolutely beautiful - jungle and the ruins both
619498435.author: a TripAdvisor user
619498435.reviewBody: We had about a half a day here with a guide from Mextrotter called Kevin.  We were with him for a week but this was one of the highlights - he is an archaeologist and had worked on some of the ruins here so his knowledge was immense and we learned a lot.  An altogether fascinating time and I recommend you go there if you are in the area.

618083443.name: Ruinas de Palenque, Chiapas
618083443.author: a TripAdvisor user
618083443.reviewBody:
I went to Palenque in a day trip from Villahermosa, Tabasco.  It's aprox a 150 km drive but it can take almost 2hrs 30min to get there.  The last 30km from Catazaja to Palenque is a road under construction and it took us 30min to get through it.  Once you get to the city of Palenque it will take like 10min to get to the archeological zone of Palenque.  Once you get there you will have to pay a fee of $35mxp per person and in the main gate to the ruins you'll be asked to pay around $70mxp per person.  

There are 2 gates in the road to see the ruins.  The 1st one includes a long walk through the jungle to get to the ruins.  If you like adventure and fitness, this is for you.  If not, continue in the road to go directly to the ruins.  

You'll find a lot of people offering guided tours and handcrafts.  Try to make your best choice and be polite if you don't want to buy something.

Make sure to bring a hat, sunblock, water...you'll need them!  It's really hot and humid!  It's the jungle!!

Bathrooms are on the entrance.  Make sure to go befor you start the visit.

The archeological ruins of Palenque are beautiful and very interesting.  Make sure to have a guide to understand it better.  Here are some pyramids you can climb.  There are just a few places where you can do this.  In most of the archeological ruins you're not alowed to climb them.

You'll also find a museum and some resorts o the road to complete your experience in Palenque.
