The Temple of the Inscriptions is beautiful (inside there is the tomb of Pakal, not possibile to visit for conservation purposes).

512033501.name: Definitely better than some others
512033501.author: a TripAdvisor user
512033501.reviewBody: We had one day in Palenque purely to go to the ruins. We left our bags at the bus station and took the collectivo - I considered the 20 peso fare to be pretty steep but obviously they are just reaping it in off the tourists as no locals have much need for the journey. You then have to pay a park fee on top of the entrance fee which also irritates me. The ruins themselves were commendable and made a nice stroll around. There was an adequate amount of information scattered around to give you an idea of what was going on. Definitely a good alternative to the over crowding you can find at Chich\u00e9n Itza

509400561.name: Beutiful
509400561.author: a TripAdvisor user
509400561.reviewBody: Amazing. Much more impressive than other ruins in Oaxaca, Chiapas, Mexico City, or in other countries in the Americas

508165588.name: Another Mayan spectacular archaeological site
508165588.author: a TripAdvisor user
508165588.reviewBody: As beautiful and as unique as Chichen Itza, Tulum or Tikal.  We took our time to explore the main ruins as well as to check out some sites less frequented by tourists.  Busy by visiting busloads, but not nearly as busy as Tulum or Chichen Itza.  There\'s an excellent museum too.

507109752.name: Great site, somewhat marred by touts
507109752.author: a TripAdvisor user
507109752.reviewBody: This is truly one of the great archeological sites in the world, comparing easily with Angkor Wat in Cambodia. It is also (relatively) easily accesible since there are nonstop flts from Mexico City to Palenque. They have discovered a lot since the mid-90s and the cleaned area is now huge. The one downfall is that unlike many other Mayan sites, this one allows sales people in the site. They do not chase you around but they are constantly blowing their flutes or making annoying jaguar sounds. One of the key pleasures of these jungle sites is being able to hear nature\'s noises. Not so here. Well worth the trip anyway but I do wish they would leave the merchants outside.

506905461.name: Outstanding ancient maya site
506905461.author: a TripAdvisor user
506905461.reviewBody: You could combine Palenque and any other leisure activity like visiting a waterfall / eco park in the many options around. If you really like ancient maya culture this place has got enough to offer for a full day. Dont forget to spend some time in the musem on site, it is outstanding, you will see original Pakal tumb and many other pieces.

506589561.name: Can\'t Help But Be in Awe of Palenque
506589561.author: a TripAdvisor user
506589561.reviewBody:
I don't know what I can add to all that has been written about the ancient Mayan city state of Palenque.  With a professional archeologist as guide, my family and I enjoyed a full day exploring the ruins of the city.

With their complex system of writing, chronology and ability as builders, the Mayans developed a huge city in the rain forest.  As much of the site as has been uncovered and restored, there is at least as much still buried under vegetation farther back in the forest.  Arranging for a trained archeologist to guide us around Palenque was one of the best things we could have done.  Rather than walking the site ourselves with little knowledge of what we were seeing or being restricted to the time frame of a large tour, we were able to choose our own pace, spend as much time as we wished and were treated to detailed information about the history of the Mayan people, their beliefs and customs as well as the significance of the major structures at Palenque.  

As a bonus, our guide was able to arrange for us to explore parts of the site that were restricted and not open to visitors.  Walking the paths and coming across small temples and mounds, still mostly covered with bushes, moss and trees made us feel as if we were explorers discovering the area for the first time.

Learning about Palenque's history while exploring the site left us with a feeling of admiration for the Mayan's complex and advanced civilization.

I do have a few criticisms or more accurately, disappointments.  Firstly, due to the tremendous popularity of Palenque, the site is too well groomed.  Palenque would have been far more interesting left in more of the original rain forest setting.  Secondly, more and more of the buildings are being closed to visitors, ostensibly to keep them from harm.  At the same time however, visitors are deprived of experiencing the full impact of the city.  Lastly, one area in the centre of the main site area is filled with vendors of local arts and crafts as well as vendors constantly blowing into instruments that gave out with  what they described as the sound of a jaguar's roar.  This was most distracting to say the least and did not fit with the ruins themselves.

Even with these accounted for, a day at Palenque should be on the priority list of any visitor to the area.  I would recommend arriving early, when the site opens in the morning the enjoy the first couple of hours free of the afternoon crowds.

506268657.name: Incredible Day at Palenque Ruins
506268657.author: a TripAdvisor user
506268657.reviewBody: Bring hat, water, sunscreen, bug repellent. Be careful walking up steep steps if hot and humid. Not much in ways to cool down if you get over heated.

505657244.name: More to Discover
505657244.author: a TripAdvisor user
505657244.reviewBody: These ruins are some of the best as you can still view areas that are covered by jungle. A guide is very good as you learn alot more about the history the people and you can climb all over them for some great views. It is very hot so take water and sun protection. There are stall sealers about but they are not pushy and some of their work is made local and not in China like so many trinkets.

504442946.name: breathtaking.
504442946.author: a TripAdvisor user
504442946.reviewBody:
you can choose to get a guide or do a little research and save yourself the hassle. 
got quoted $85usd for an English Speaking Guide. Extortion. 
$600pesos for a Spanish speaking guide. 
The whole experience was great.

504442353.author: a TripAdvisor user
504442353.reviewBody: The ruins are absolutely phenomenal and very well kept - definitely worth a visit! We went without a guide, but found the descriptions in front of structures sufficient for a start. Don\'t forget to stop by the Site Museum on the way out!

504438853.name: Impressive! beautiful place.
504438853.author: a TripAdvisor user
504438853.reviewBody:
I have visited the most important ruins in Mexico by now and the ones in Palenque is very special because of it's location in the jungle. The place is very well taken care of. You spend about 3-4 hrs if you explore it all and climb whatever you can. There are many well kept structures. The waterfall also very nice.  Actually just a fabulous place. 

My only BUT here for me was that you have people trying to sell you anything inside and outside the ruins, you were constantly followed by kids wanting to tell you a story for a tip and followed by people selling you from water to shoes. Outside the ruins there is already a "market" which gives locals the opportunity to offer their products so I don't see the need to have them following you through your visit. BTW I am a local so I can compare very well to other places/sightseeing in the country. This "commercial" activities in and by the entrance of the ruins is very pushy and partly uncomfortable even for us as locals.  I hope this review is read by the INAH. 

In any case, that is not reason enough to miss this wonderful place.

502655673.name: Superb!
502655673.author: a TripAdvisor user
502655673.reviewBody:
Great place well kept and superb must see if traveling to Chiapas! 
Please go with a guide  to hear the explanations of the so many places.
Itnis very hot and high humidity

502306384.name: Just incredible!
502306384.author: a TripAdvisor user
502306384.reviewBody: The ruins of Palenque are incredibles! You have the jungle part and the ruins. It\'s not so crowd, there is a lot of space. You can heard the monkeys in the morning.

501758577.name: Best ruins in Mexico and a must see
501758577.author: a TripAdvisor user
501758577.reviewBody: We planned on a month long vacation to Mexico with the intention of seeing Palenque ruins. The ruins just blew our minds in the scale and planning of the city. The Palenque ruins is reminiscent of Angkor Wat in Cambodia. It\'s best to see the ruins as soon as it opens - around 8 am. We stayed in El Panchan so we had easy access to the ruins. The museum was closed which was a pity. Be sure to go through the waterfalls when exiting through the museum. Proper footwear is recommended as the climb is quite slippery. Palenque is the jewel of Mexico!

500846573.name: Circus.
500846573.author: a TripAdvisor user
500846573.reviewBody: This was my 4th Maya site. Unfortunately I was left a little disappointed. The ruins themselves are really impressive, and probably the best I\'ve seen, however, I was disappointed with the way it presents itself. It\'s a bit of a circus, with vendors, artisans and hawkers crowding the whole place, outside the entrance and all the way along the pathways inside the site. Tikal and Copan were so much nicer. In my opinion the circus should be kept outside of the gates so the site can be enjoyed for it\'s serenity an d beauty as well as for the ruins.

500561238.name: Wow
500561238.author: a TripAdvisor user
500561238.reviewBody: Palenque ruins  is one of the most beautiful  place I have been breath taking I really  don\'t know how  anybody can really get the whole experience on a 4 hour tour I spent 4 days there climbed every pyramid  sat down and got a chance to soak up all the wonders palenque  had to offer  if mayan ruin interest you this is the place to go you will not regret  it and the people  in palenque city are pretty good to

500514861.name: Great
500514861.author: a TripAdvisor user
500514861.reviewBody: It was warm, not really hot; but intensely humid. We were both wet by the time we finished. We decided to hire a guide and we\'re glad that we did. Salvador was a font of information and very solicitous to me going up and down steps. We went into the jungle and he showed us where there were a number of ruins yet to be uncovered. There is a lot that hasn\'t been cleared. The entire area you could tell was a city; even without seeing the map showing everything. Very interesting. So many different structures, we were able to climb up and in a number of them. Truly spectacular.

499521112.name: Great Experience!
499521112.author: a TripAdvisor user
499521112.reviewBody: Went to Palenque with a group of coworkers on a weekend when we played hookie from work... anyway, I am ashamed to admit that I had never heard of Palenque before and did not know what to expect! Despite this, I am now super glad I went! It was beyond awesome that you are still able to climb the pyramids, unlike Chichen Itza! Hopefully it stays that way for long time so others can appreciate the beauty and the architecture. We went in May and it was SUPER, SUPER HUMID!!! The kind of humidity where you can\'t really breathe but that did not take away the happiness and joy I felt as I climbed the pyramids and marbled at the detail that was put into the construction of such beauty! \nI do agree with other comments that mentioned that there were a lot of vendors surrounding the pyramids! It\'s not as bad as in ChiChen Itza, but it would have been better if there were less vendors! Overall, I highly, highly recommend you check this place out and experience the beauty of Palenque! You will not be disappointed!

498070876.name: Marvelous destination.
498070876.author: a TripAdvisor user
498070876.reviewBody: Having done my research well ahead of time, I knew that approaching Palenque from the south could be risky. I\'d read about the road-blocks and robberies that sometimes happen in Chiapas and opted to make our way from Tabasco in the north. We flew into Villahermosa on the 18th of June and took a taxi to Chan-Kah Resort Village on the following day. There was no incident of any kind on our two-hour ride. On the morning of the 20th we hiked from the resort to the park and archeological zone. Would you believe that there are paved bicycle lanes running all the way from downtown Palenque to the park? In any event, when you arrive at the park entrance (after touring the fantastic site-museum) you can either go forward on the road (long, winding and not shaded) or go left through the "jungle entrance". We chose the later. That was a great option for us. Sure, it was all up-hill on stone stairs (lots and lots of stone stairs) but we had the shade of the jungle, the company of waterfalls, and a glimpse of wonders to come. The "Bats Group" of ruins and the "Queen\'s Bath" are not to be missed. They made it clear to us how a "primitive" people could have clean running water and comfortable homes. The greatest reward of the Jungle Entrance, however, is at the trail\'s end. You take the final stairs and emerge from the jungle into the main site. The daunting presence of The Palace appears along with a few of the lesser-known temples. Only a few feet more and the Temple of Inscriptions begins to peak from around a corner. I had been concerned that the ruins would be unimpressive, but those worries were dashed to dust as we wandered through these majestic, ancient structures. They are, in fact, bigger and more imposing that I had imagined. It was 92 degrees Fahrenheit that day, with a heat-index of 104, but we didn\'t care. The next several hours were spent exploring the temples. We were even able to go inside the Palace and look out from the t-shaped windows! We saw the cinnabar-coated tomb of the Red Queen and the intact art inside the Temple of the Foliated Cross. After several hours of wonder we walked down to the main site-entrance. Lots of vendors there, as on the temple grounds, which was perfect because we desperately needed water and wanted to pick up a few souvenirs. On our second visit, two days later, we capped-off a similar but more extensive excursion with a hike to Templo Olvidado, the "Forgotten Temple". Only for the adventurous! If you want to feel like Indiana Jones for a couple up hours, just stroll down the road from the Archeological Zone until you reach Sendero Motiepa. Apply insect repellent, make sure you have good hiking shoes on, and go find Pakal\'s first (and least excavated) construction project. We were too tired (and mosquito-bitten) afterward to walk all the way back to the resort, but we caught a ride for 10 pesos each. Two great days spent at the Palenque Ruinas.

496819994.name: Don\'t waste your time. Highway roads to Palenque are being blocked by locals demanding the government
496819994.author: a TripAdvisor user
496819994.reviewBody: Roads to palenque are being blocked by local people demanding the government a new highway.  Waste of time and money.  We had to go back after 3 hours of driving time

495999102.name: ot as big nor as impressive as some other ruins that I have been to
495999102.author: a TripAdvisor user
495999102.reviewBody:
I was GRANDPAcking in El Panchan for 1 week.
I walked to the ruins from El Panchan (about 50 minutes) and spent a couple of hours at the archaeological site.
It is not a big site ... you can see it all in 2 hours.
The Palace is fairly impressive and it has a nice, restored temple.
There is no big pyramid to climb.
One of the nice things about the site is the 700 meter jungle walk as you exit the ruins ... passing past a small waterfall and some of the old washing / bathing sites.

495887913.name: Nice ruins
495887913.author: a TripAdvisor user
495887913.reviewBody: If you come at 8am you\'ll have the place completely to yourself for half an hour. You can also enter through the museum(same ticket) and walk a path past a waterfall to the ruins. Or the other way round. Museum only opens at 9am. You can climb most structures at least partly. \nComparing it to the 2 other Maya ruins(Ek Balam and Chichen Itza) I\'ve been to I\'d rank it last.

495860393.name: Very significant Archeological site
495860393.author: a TripAdvisor user
495860393.reviewBody: We were a little undecided if we should bypass Palenque and the ruins as it is a drive and a half from San Cristobal ( like 6 hours! Including a stop at the  waterfalls) but it has been an excellent area. \nThe ruins are amazing and only 10% are uncovered. It is a very large site and our guide took us on the jungle trail were you can still see areas of the ruins untouched and covered in trees and jungle growth, truly amazing and very interesting. \nThe uncovered and restored sites are quite significant and are another testimony of the ability and knowledge of the Aztec and Mayan civilisation which existed in those times, truly magnificent.

494396281.name: 2017MexicoAdventure
494396281.author: a TripAdvisor user
494396281.reviewBody: What an amazing, beautiful and peaceful place to visit. This Ruins are so impressive with so much to see and learn. So well conserved, this place holds some sort of tranquility which makes you admire every little detail. I really want to go back to this and discover more as they are much more to learn and see.\nWild life can be heard all around this place, so keep your eyes open as you take a walk around the jungle.\n

494067781.name: Vacation
494067781.author: a TripAdvisor user
494067781.reviewBody: Went to see the ruins with my brother.  We had an excellent time.  It was a very interesting experience.

493930144.name: Extraordinary
493930144.author: a TripAdvisor user
493930144.reviewBody:
We opted for a private tour guide.  His name is Edgar.  Find Edgar!
In addition to a comprehensive tour of the ruins, we were treated to pertinent information about Mayan culture, mathematics, food and much more.  On a hiking tour through the jungle, Edgar shared indigenous plants used for medicine, cooking and everyday Mayan life.  He showed us exactly how the jungle claims ruins and just how difficult they are to find and unearth.  
What appeared to be a small sinkhole or cave in the jungle floor turned out to be a chamber in a buried Mayan structure replete with small fruit bats.  
Sharing the rich history and culture of Palenque isn't just Edgar's job- it's his heritage and his passion.  
Edgar turned already breathtaking ruins into an experience that I will be digesting and appreciating for months.

Find Edgar!

492777590.name: A Look into the Past
492777590.author: a TripAdvisor user
492777590.reviewBody: We were a small group and had our own guide. There were a lot of tour guides who tried to get us to use them but once inside the park we enlisted a young man who was not yet a tour guide. Our own guide said he would have more detailed information as he is part of the community. He didn\'t speak English but our guide translated. He even did some fun panoramic photos for us. A great experience to explore ruins - crazy that so much more is hidden in the forest yet to be uncovered.

492590883.name: Must see Mayan Ruins
492590883.author: a TripAdvisor user
492590883.reviewBody: The Palenque Mayan ruins are a must see attraction if you are interested in Mayan culture. There are many different ways to get there, including hiking or biking (around 9 kms) along a purpose built trail that reflects Palenque\'s growing eco credentials. You will have to pay two small access fees along the way - a National Park entry fee, and Palenque Ruins entry fee. The services of a guide would be an additional charge, and our English speaking guide was relatively expensive but worth the expense if you are visiting like we were as a small group. Prices, of course, are negotiable. The guide adds a whole other layer to the experience, and are very knowledgeable when it comes to the nooks and crannies of the ruins that you may ordinarily miss. Three hours is a good length of time for the highlights tour, but you could spend many days following many different trails as much of the site has yet to be excavated.

491830154.name: Great day trip!
491830154.author: a TripAdvisor user
491830154.reviewBody: We stayed in el panchan for 2 nights specifically to visit the Palenque Ruins, and we were not disappointed. By far the best Ruins in Mexico with relatively small crowds if you get up early enough!\n\nWould definitely recommend staying in El Panchan (hippie commune) instead of Palenque city as it is closer with better relaxed vibes!

491303804.name: Amazing ruins, but maybe not in June?
491303804.author: a TripAdvisor user
491303804.reviewBody: We arrived at 8:30 and left by noon. By the time we left, the heat index was 105. All the interesting ruins are in one general area and they are magnificent, especially the palace. You cannot go into the temple of inscriptions to see the tomb of Pacal, which was really disappointing, but you can go into a few temples...unlike in Tulum or Chitzen Itza. Do NOT do the trail that follows the river way down to the museum. It was steep, slippery, and like a steam bath. No interesting  ruins but there were a couple nice waterfalls that you CAN\'T swim in!!! Once we got to the museum, we were dying for some AC, but it was closed on Mondays!!! Otherwise the ruins are amazing and can\'t be missed.

489494180.name: one of the best
489494180.author: a TripAdvisor user
489494180.reviewBody: we have visited lots of mayan ruins and this one is special!  pretty hot, but you can find some shade.  we didn\'t think we would be that impressed, but ended up staying for 7 hours

488353280.name: Great place to see
488353280.author: a TripAdvisor user
488353280.reviewBody: Mayan ruins surrounded by jungle.  Great museum.  A fantastic place to visit.  Not busy at all in late April.

488199244.name: Huge Mayan Ruins Dont miss it!
488199244.author: a TripAdvisor user
488199244.reviewBody: Had a great day doing Palenque ruins. HINT:  Dont buy a guided tour outside the place. Once inside there will  be many Free-Lancers who will do a tour (Just as complete)  for MUCH Less!\n\nBring comfortable walking shoes Hat etc  Its a very HOT place.  If you\'re "into" Mayan Ruins  this is a  must see!

487878577.name: Breath taking
487878577.author: a TripAdvisor user
487878577.reviewBody: Definitely worth the visit! The park is huge and the ruins are amazing to see! You  can get a tour guide or wander freely

487637788.name: Stunning
487637788.author: a TripAdvisor user
487637788.reviewBody: Went twice to this ruins, once with a guided tour that covered Misol-Ha and Agua Azul in the same day. As the time was about 3 hours for the conducted tour, I felt it was insufficient and went alone on the second day to properly explore this stunning Maya site built between 226 BC and 799 AD.\nThe restoration work done by the government is fascinating. There are so many structures to see and explore.

487557914.name: A Must See.
487557914.author: a TripAdvisor user
487557914.reviewBody: These ruins have of course been reconstructed (as are all Mayan ruins) but they have been done well and many of their secret chambers etc uncovered. It gives you a good understanding of how life was at that time especially if you have a knowledgeable guide.

487545925.name: Best ruins in Mexico
487545925.author: a TripAdvisor user
487545925.reviewBody: Very well reserved and green. You can imagine how they lived in this place once upon a time. close to a jungle.

486256259.name: Great cultural experience
486256259.author: a TripAdvisor user
486256259.reviewBody: Not much to say since they name says it all. It is a great testament to human ingenuity. The place is amazing. The only downside is that they allow vendors inside the park and it takes away from the experience of trying experience the ruins. Nobody wants hawking their wares while you are trying to read and enjoy the ruins. Which by the way, they charge for/

485654430.name: Highlight of any Mexico tour
485654430.author: a TripAdvisor user
485654430.reviewBody: This site is spectacular and well worth half a day exploring and just relaxing at to take in the sites. there are royal palace buildings and sacrificial temples. The site is full of gory propaganda from the past royalty enforcing their sense of achievement in terms of both wars with neighbours and connectivity to the gods. Plenty of blood was spilled to placate the gods and evidence of this is all around. The layout is different to most pre-Colombian sites as the main buildings are of a royal enclosure. A good guide brings this all to life. Be prepare for heat and little shade. There is a museum outside the site to give more detail to the story of the ruins. Be prepared to spend at least half a day there to maximise your visit and also be prepared for a lot of climbing and extended walking.

485584483.name: Incredibly well maintained Mayan ruins.
485584483.author: a TripAdvisor user
485584483.reviewBody: The ruins are extensive and are a sight to behold. Many focus on the rule of Pakal, who claimed the throne at 12. The archeological site is in the middle of the jungle and the humidity is quite overwhelming. Regardless, definitely a worthwhile visit.

485194468.name: Magic and spectacular!
485194468.author: a TripAdvisor user
485194468.reviewBody:
You can go by car or by public transportation (around 25 pesos - you can take it in front of the ADO bus station). It is +/- 15 min from the city.

You need to pay two fee entrances. One is for the entrance to the Protected Natural Area where is located the archaeological zone, the second one is for the entrance to the pyramids. 

Try to be there as early as possible, you will enjoy the site with less tourists. Bring water with you and sunscreen.

484988892.name: Absolutely Mesmerising
484988892.author: a TripAdvisor user
484988892.reviewBody:
Palenque Ruins are absolutely astonishing. I was here before in 2011 and was delighted to get the chance to go back again.
The whole complex is incredible with beautiful temples everywhere you look. The access you are given is second to none, obviously you can't climb them but you can walk right up to them and see them right in detail.
When you walk up to the temples the view you have of the laws and valley below is stunning and all the other temples along the strip are so majestic.
For the second time I have to say that the guards were pretty horrible. I remember being shouted at for absolutely no reason on my first visit when a guard mistook me for someone else who had the temerity to sit on a monument. he refused to back down and got righ tin my face.
Regrettable... and almost unbelievably almost the same thing happened again. We were walking along the gravel path and a guide was giving a tour. he absolutely roared at us for getting between his group and a temple. We really had no choice as it was the marked path! It is never nice to get yelled at, especially for nothing! I know what you are thinking, there's two sides to every story! Not this time! We rally did nothing wrong.
But don't let horrible little people like that get in the way of your enjoyment, I certainly didn't. The place gets 5 stars, some of the employees get 0.

484861955.name: Not enough time
484861955.author: a TripAdvisor user
484861955.reviewBody: This is a fantastic site and well worth exploring.  However, we set off from San Cristobal very early morning, stopping at Aqua Azul en route and eventually got to the ruins so late we only had time to scratch the surface.\nIf you are on a guided tour like we were bear in mind the road from San Cristobal is dire and a journey time quoted of four and a half hours ended up at seven and a half!!\nStill enjoyed our short time there though.

484519105.name: From out fo the jungle, the incredible Palenque
484519105.author: a TripAdvisor user
484519105.reviewBody: Get there early, get there early, get there early . . . then spend the day among the awe inspiring ruins of Palenque. Wear comfortable walking shoes, bring plenty of water, & something to snack on, & of course your camera. If you get there at 8 a.m. before all the tourists & buses get there, you\'ll be able to enjoy the ruins for an hour or 2 before the hundreds of people arrive. The ruins are absolutely incredible, all the temples & buildings are worth exploring, so take your time & enjoy each one. If you don\'t know much about the Maya or the ruins, join a group and /or hire a guide. Also make an attempt to buy goods from the local Mayan women or children. . . And don\'t forget to save an at least an hour on the way down the mountain to stop at the small museum down the gated entrance.

484504453.name: Ruinas de pakal
484504453.author: a TripAdvisor user
484504453.reviewBody: A must see if your anywhere in Chiapas. It is a bit of a stretch to get here because the roads are very windy but it\'s worth it! Make sure to get a loca tour guide prices tend to be much cheaper especially if you get it in Spanish. The architecture is astonishing! Make sure you go as early as you can because it gets extremely hot in April.

483919431.name: Beautiful! A Must See for Lovers of Ancient History! Go now!
483919431.author: a TripAdvisor user
483919431.reviewBody:
Go early!

Let me say this again. Go early! The site opened at 8 am. I got there at 7:45 and was the first person in. I pretty much had everything to myself for about 30 minutes. And even after that, it was not the madhouse that some places (like Teotihuacan) can be. The ruins are extremely well maintained and in the jungle, but there are still very nice paths to walk along. There are guides at the front of the site. I am sure they are fine, but I was able to do the whole thing by myself without them. I was there in late April and while the general feeling was warm and humid, it was not over-poweringly so. Also there were NO BUGS (I did have the proper bug repellant though). Do climb everything that you can. These ancient sites are getting more and more traffic, so as the years go by, they are beginning to close access to many of the structures. Not just here, but all over. So experience it while you can. Also, many of the structures have points of interest at the top (not to mention views), so make the effort. And leave your pride at home. Some of these things are tall and have no safety rails. So if you need to "sit and scooch" on the way down or climb up on all fours, do it. One pointer... there are signs in Spanish and English that are all around. They are very basic, Don't depend on either them or the (somewhat) confusing maps. Get an idea of the lay of the land before you go. But don't let that deter you. The reality is that the site is less complicated to navigate than say the San Diego Zoo or Sea World.
Do take your water and a nice snack, or even a light lunch. There are plenty of places to sit in the shade and have a break. I even took a nap on an ancient temple with a view of the palace. When I woke up an iguana was basking in the sun next to me.
And do explore the structures in their entirety, as is allowed. There are clear signs telling you where you can and cannot go. Many people just sort of went up and came back down. But after going to the top of the large Palace structure I decided to come down an opposite side and lo and behold there was a small (unmarked) entrance to a series of lit tunnels that honeycombed inside the structure. Very Indiana Jones. It wasn't on the maps and I was the only person inside.

Go EARLY!

Also most importantly, there are I believe, 2 entrances. Do NOT go in via the entrance by the museum! If you do this, you will need to climb up a steep (but attractive) jungle path that traverses a fun suspension bridge and waterfall before you get to the ruins. Instead use the entrance at the top that pretty much dumps you right into the heart of the ruins. After a few hours, when you are done exploring all of the big ruins on top and have had your nap/snack break/iguana encounter, THEN go down the path to the waterfall and museum. It will be later in the day so walking down hill  on a shaded path to the sound of trickling water will be a welcome respite. 

And DO go into the museum. That is where they have the big sarcophogus (that all of us boomers saw on In Search of Ancients Astronauts. 

Don't worry. You can get transportation back to wherever you need to from both sites. Palenque is a very small town, but they are almost entirely tourist driven, so they make it easy.

483918863.name: Very interesting
483918863.author: a TripAdvisor user
483918863.reviewBody:
My wife and I went here and by chance came across a very good guide, his name is Edgar, was a archeological student as well as a anthropology student and well knowledgeable about what he is talking about, any way we hired him for the Raina's walk + a jungle walk where we saw a Mayan swimming pool all really awesome.
We started in the ruins where we started with the red queens tomb, then moved on to the other pyramids, with and explanation of the king and his sons, the tour took about two hours, the it was off to the jungle for that tour, we walked for about a half hour where he pointed out dwelling cover by the jungle, then we got to the swimming pool. WOW, the pool had been excavated years earlier, but had gradually. started to fill in again, Edgar explained that sometime in the near future they were going to drain and excavate again a more permeate fix this time.
The pool is constantly being cleaned because a stream flows through it and then out, he then took us a few steps away to what he said was the rebirth for the mayans, it was a cave that the stream ran through, upon entering it got pitch black, then you rounded the corner and there was the light, or rebirth.
I know it all sound a little corny, but it was pretty amazing. So if you eat the Palanque ruins and need and english speaking guide I would recommend Edgar.

PS we also employed his services out to the Yaxchilan and Bonampak ruins.

482104445.name: A lost Mayan city that lies waiting to be discovered
482104445.author: a TripAdvisor user
482104445.reviewBody:
Palenque is a unique site amongst the Mayan ruins across Mexico and Guatemala.

Being buried in the jungle means that when you walk through nature, you're actually walking on the buildings themselves, right under your feet.

It adds a mystery and charm to the place - alongside the impressive structures and pyramids that you will come to expect when spending time in the region.

You feel like a genuine explorer, and it's a very special feeling.

481805161.name: One of my favourite maya sites
481805161.author: a TripAdvisor user
481805161.reviewBody: The ruins are in the middle of the jungle. It looks really amazing. I spent a few hours there discovering temples and palaces. There\'s also a bit distant part with a small waterfall and older ruins. Also it\'s possible to take a van from that part back to the town so it\'s worthy of a short walk.\nIt\'s qiute hot in Palenque so it\'s better if have with you a lot of water.

481029292.name: Breathtaking Mayan Site
481029292.author: a TripAdvisor user
481029292.reviewBody: Amazing pyramids in the middle of tropical rain forests-extremely humid and hot. Must see site if you travel to south Mexico.

480513544.name: Spend your time and try to arrive early
480513544.author: a TripAdvisor user
480513544.reviewBody:
We ( 4 adults and 3 kids) spent almost 5hours .. And it was great
We took a guide for the ruins (so many details to see .. That we could have missed alone) and we took the same guide for going into the jungle and see what can be a 1400 temples still not discovered! 
That was an interesting part and it is worth for it !!!
The 2 tours cost (in Spanish) was 2600 $mx (3200 $mx if you ask for another language)
Just an important advise = during the week end go there very early in order to avoid the crowd and the heat !

479607662.name: Amazing
479607662.author: a TripAdvisor user
479607662.reviewBody: Well, the place is just, AMAZING.\nI didn\'t expect anything like that, much better then the chaotic chichen itza.\nThe price is also really cheap. Small tip: go in the early morning, its hard to survive with that hot temperature.

479503804.name: Amazing!
479503804.author: a TripAdvisor user
479503804.reviewBody: Just go! Right now!  Book a ticket and go.  We loved, loved, loved our time here.  The English speaking tours are expensive - $190 USD for 3 hours BUT it includes a guided tour into the jungle where only tour guides can take people.  The jungle section was amazing because there are so many unexcavated ruins in the jungle.  Our guide stayed with us for over 4 hours at no additional cost.  Ask for Victor at the guide stand.  He is amazing!  One Tip:  Get there early!  Like 7:30am.  There is VERY limited parking, ticket lines get long and it gets hot.  We were some of the first ones into the park and Victor took us around to take pictures with no one in the background.

479494374.name: Go early for the monkeys
479494374.author: a TripAdvisor user
479494374.reviewBody: Another spectacular example from the Maya.  This is not to be missed.  Different than Chichen or Uxmal or those along the Ruta Puuc as the jungle is more dense.  Go early as there can be monkeys and it will be slightly cooler as it does get steamy.  Don\'t forget to look a the various plants and birds.

479435579.name: Lost in the jungle (among merchants)
479435579.author: a TripAdvisor user
479435579.reviewBody: The best ruins in Mexico, as long as you prefer natural settings (no desert, dry stones, etc)\nIn the middle of the real jungle, where unknow and unidentified noises and sounds run above your head  all day long, you find yourself in a real "Indiana Jones" d\u00e9cor, which can only inspire respect for the people who built those temple.... until you are called by a merchant sitting everywhere to sell their worthless souvenir

477912312.name: Great visit, hire a guide
477912312.author: a TripAdvisor user
477912312.reviewBody: We recently visited the Archeological Zone of Palenque and were thrilled to see the famous structures of that have been already been uncovered, but were also fortunate enough to take a strenuous 90-minute hike through the thick jungle, climbing to the top of what was the highest pyramid in Palenque.  The massive pyramid is part of the 90% of the ancient city that is still completely covered by jungle.  All along the primitive jungle path we could see evidence of the Mayan structure below: brief glimpses of a massive stone base, the outlines of several arches, and large stones protruding from the roots of enormous trees.  This is what the first European explorers saw when they arrived at the Mayan site in 1840, and it is almost impossible to imagine the work that went into revealing what we can see today.\nThere is no way we could, or would undertake such a trek through the jungle by ourselves.  We hired an official guide at the entrance to the site and he led us on a 4.5 hour visit through the spectacular ruins of Palenque and some of the surrounding jungle.\nVictor, our guide, was a short, round, middle-aged man who set a brisk pace for our tour, scrambling up and down the steps of pyramids and palaces, then waiting patiently in the shade for us to catch up.  His English was quite good, as was his French, German and Italian, and he did an excellent job of explaining the history and architecture of the buildings, as well as pointing out many interesting decorative details.  He also used our camera to take many photos of the two of us throughout our tour.  Official prices are posted for the guides and, while they are not cheap, they are worth the expense.

476222119.name: nice site, beautiful impressive ruins, the view from the temple of the sun is fabulous.
476222119.author: a TripAdvisor user
476222119.reviewBody: the view from the temple of the sun is fabulous. Go in early to catch some monkeys and birds unaware. There is a park entrance fee for the eco-park and a second fee for the archeological site. Parking was free in March-April 2017, don\'t let them rip you off ("para cuidar el carro..."). Guides available at the entrance, bring sunblock and a hat (really).

475558934.name: Must Do
475558934.author: a TripAdvisor user
475558934.reviewBody:
One of the most mystical cities from
The Mayan empire, totally worth the travel, a place full of magic in the middle of the real Mexican jungle.

Surrounded by thick jungle in a protected
Park, one of Mexico's hidden treasures, super nice local ppl, you support local Indigenous communities and artisans 

For sure a place to visit before you die

475109638.name: Magical place
475109638.author: a TripAdvisor user
475109638.reviewBody: The beauty of this archeological place is unique. You can still climb the pyramids and explore trails behind main buildings. We saw wild animals while walking in the trails.

473666135.name: incredible!
473666135.author: a TripAdvisor user
473666135.reviewBody: the most incredible archaeological site in Mexico. The surrounding with the jungle makes it special. Also the possibility to climb the ruins.\nand as many mentioned: beats Chichen Itza! \nnowadays, the main problem to get to Palenque is the "roads blockade"..we had to round about 6 hours by car to get to the Palenque ruins.

473408829.name: Excellent archeological spot in the jungle
473408829.author: a TripAdvisor user
473408829.reviewBody: I liked the green area (rainforest) compared to other sites in Mexico in March. Here it is evergreen and the ruins are interesting. Worth a guide who explains you the mayan engineering stuff like aqueducts, sauna, house ventilation solutions.\nIt is possible to take a walk through the jungle as well and see undiscovered ruinas.

472533128.name: Beats Chichen-Itza
472533128.author: a TripAdvisor user
472533128.reviewBody: These are some of my favourite ruins in Mexico. Ive been twice, 7 years apart, and both times there have been relatively few tourists. The ruins are intricate, come with interesting history and feel very peaceful amongst the rainforest. Well worth visiting!

472245338.name: Beautiful
472245338.author: a TripAdvisor user
472245338.reviewBody: We really liked the ruins. The surrounding with the jungle makes it special. The only thing we did not like is all the sales people inside the ruin area. That is a bit too much and does not fit to the atmosphere

471579223.name: Highlight of our trip
471579223.author: a TripAdvisor user
471579223.reviewBody: We entered the park in the first entrance, walking up through the jungle by a small river. Then we arrived at the ruins. They are huge and you can climb up all of them. Great place to make beautiful pictures. Very nice experience.

470974153.name: A MUST in Mexico!
470974153.author: a TripAdvisor user
470974153.reviewBody: I hired a guide for this trip and it started at 8am. It was the low season but many tourists were scattered all over the amazingly mysterious Mayan ruins. Less than 10% of the site has been excavated, and you need a guide to identity areas that are under excavation. Without the guide, I would have thought it was just normal hills. Although locals will tell you no mosquitos during the earlier part of the year, please do apply deep based DEET insect repellent as I saw some tourists bitten by some unknown bugs while exploring the site. Temperature will increase rapidly and before you know it, you will be perspiring under the scorching sun. Bring WATER and apply lots of sunscreen lotion. \nAccording to research, the site can be explored within 2-3 hours, but I disagree. Including the museum at the bottom of the archeological site (if you enter from the main entrance, you will be led to the main square, and you will follow the crowd to explore some villages going down, and the hill into the jungle, and out from another exit, cross the road and into the museum), I took almost 5 hours. Don\'t forget due to the scorching high temperature and humidity, you need to rest at numerous stops. Plus you need to climb up all the different temples and some can be very steep. So give yourself more time and do not rush.

470853551.name: A must See
470853551.author: a TripAdvisor user
470853551.reviewBody: Go early, take your time.  Not too many vendors to distract you, but enough to shop for those gifts if you are lookng

470626560.name: Extensive ruins
470626560.author: a TripAdvisor user
470626560.reviewBody: Stunning ruins in a jungle setting. Lots of opportunity to explore,walk around and climb the ruins. Well worth at least 4-5 hours. Museum is also worth seeing.

470352328.name: Amazing experience
470352328.author: a TripAdvisor user
470352328.reviewBody: Probably one of the best places in the world, I enjoyed the every corner of the ancient city. Just remember to bring water and comfortable shoes

470294291.name: Palenque Ruins
470294291.author: a TripAdvisor user
470294291.reviewBody: Visiting Palenque was a really great experience. We went on X-Mas day 2016 and stayed in a nearby cabin found on AirBnb. Palenque is one of the largest Mayan Ruins in the region. We hired our own guide and he took us through covered and uncovered pyramids. We learned a lot about Mayan history, the ruler of this village Pakal, the culture and trade industries, and even language which some of the locals still spoke and preserved. Also really suggest going to Cantona if you like having the freedom to climb the actual pyramids.

470233217.name: My favourite ruins in Mexico
470233217.author: a TripAdvisor user
470233217.reviewBody: Palenque rising out of the jungle is stunning,  you can just imagine how the explorers felt when they discovered it! It feels quite different to other ruins, being surrounded by greenery, but is so interesting with combs rising at the top of pyramids and an observatory.... really interesting place. Lots of souvenir sellers all through the site, which can be a shame wirh some of the photograph opportunities,  but that seems to just be the Mexican way!  A really fascinating site, with a wonderful feel to it, especially first thing in the morning with the sun coming through.  A must see!

469934075.name: Breathtaking
469934075.author: a TripAdvisor user
469934075.reviewBody: Maybe a bit more crowded than Tikal in Guatemala but definitely worth a visit.  The ruins are surrounded by 50 shades of junglegreen which makes the site pictureperfect. Awesome that most of the ruins can be climbed. From the top the views are simply stunning.  We drove almost 800 kilometers to see palenque, but the ruins were so worth it. Don\'t forget to visit the museum. Very informative.

469200695.name: INDIANA JONES TYPE RUINS!
469200695.author: a TripAdvisor user
469200695.reviewBody: I was on a tour of Mexico so had seen a LOT of archeological sites by the time I got to Palenque .. so what makes this one special?? Simply put it\'s the SETTING... located in the Jungle with a lush green jungle backdrop and the screeching of monkeys in the distance this is different from the rest.  The architecture is stunning and it is the one site I could actually imagine what it was like back in the day.  I had a good guide so that helped .. but this for me was the GEM of all the Mexican sites I visited and far better than the in my opinion overrated Chichen Itza.

468979198.name: Fabulous Mayan site
468979198.author: a TripAdvisor user
468979198.reviewBody: We loved these ruins and the history of the Mayan people. Very impressive when you consider only 10% of this site has been cleared from the jungle

468966023.name: Very impressive ruins!!
468966023.author: a TripAdvisor user
468966023.reviewBody: These are definitely some of the greatest ruins I have seen in Mexico. They are hidden inside the jungle which gives such a cool atmosphere. I love that you are able to climb some of the ruins and are able to go inside and see the wall drawings. It gets crowded in the afternoon but not as crowded as Chichen Itza. Palenque is much more peaceful. I really recommend this place!

468499883.name: If you only ever visit one ruined Maya city
468499883.author: a TripAdvisor user
468499883.reviewBody: Palenque ruins are amongst the most spectacular in Mexico.  The site is beautifully presented and the buildings rise up out of the jungle.  Apart from the wonderful plazas, palaces and temples, this area is excellent for wildlife.  You will certainly hear parrots and almost certainly see them.\nOver the past couple of decades these ruins have become extremely popular and you will not have the place to yourself.  It is, however, still possible to find some quieter places in the site.\nThere are a number of traders inside the site and they sell items that make a noise (supposedly like a jaguar though it\'s more like a howler monkey).  Children love these - I don\'t.

467492809.name: Jungle Ruins!
467492809.author: a TripAdvisor user
467492809.reviewBody: I saw a lot of ruins during my time in Cnetral America and Palenque was one of my favourites. Less touristy than Chichen Itza so doesnt feel quite as crowded. If you know little about the Mayans I\'d recommend getting a guide to explain it all because it is fascinating!  Walking through the jungle to get to these ruins we heard and saw Howler monkeys !

467442214.name: really good
467442214.author: a TripAdvisor user
467442214.reviewBody: Lovely jungle setting. Howler monkeys in the background added to the atmosphere. Excellent small museum at exit - well worth a visit.

466225665.name: South Mexico best sight
466225665.author: a TripAdvisor user
466225665.reviewBody: Really huge.. this Mayan site is unique. The guided tour is really expensive. My advice do not take the 3 hours guided tour. The guide will propose to sight and " Jungle " tour but it s not necessary... you can take one hour and half guided tour for the ruine  and go by your self to do the jungle beside. \nTo visits palenque come in the early morning the sight opens at 8 o\'clock. Few people are there at the morning and the sun color are just magical on the ruins. When you finish the ruin visit then the jungle most people go to the museum directly. Don\'t do that. Finish the jungle tour then go back to the ruin to take the exit. This allows you to see the ruin with noon colors take a last sight of this huge monument and specially easy bet back to you car. Go to the museum by car since it s in the sight exist. Going back on foot from museum to the parking is not pleasant. Wish you a good sightseeing in palenque!

465703943.name: The powerful world of Maya
465703943.author: a TripAdvisor user
465703943.reviewBody: Discover the ruins of Palenque in the heart of Chiapas, one of the most important site of the Maya civilization. You don\'t need a guide if you check before to visit some tips on Youtube. The story is amazing. The main entrance is the best way to go on site. You will pay 45 pesos to join the entrance and 75 pesos to go inside the ruins. You will listen the jungle music and discover how the Mayan were smart and evolved. They had current water in each Pyramids when we lived in the Middle Age in France.

465145673.name: Jungle, pyramids you allowed to climb and outstanding museum
465145673.author: a TripAdvisor user
465145673.reviewBody:
Most of visitors are staying the night in Palenque town, so it is easy to be at the entrance at opening time. Going in at 8 AM, you can get some hour for yourself at the site, and it is the best you can do. Ruins are picturesque, but the centre of mayan city is rather compact and to skip the crowds is to prefer. Some pyramids are still open for visiting, as Red Queen pyramid, and some is still possible to climb as a Pyramid of the Sun and Pyramid of the Cross. They lay a bit aside from the Palace complex, and in the morning it is tranquil and pleasant quiet spot, where you can climb up in a shade. 
The walking path through the area begins at the upper entrance, going through the central part of former mayan city with most known pyramids and buildings, and then going down through a jungle, some 1-1,5 km, to the lower entrance and Museum of the site. Descending path is a long series of steps, often wet and slippery, which going through a real jungle with high trees, passing springs, waterfalls, a hanging bridge and a few minor archeological areas, so a comfortable shoes are to prefer.
Museum of the site shows artefacts from the archeological excavations and finds from the area. The sarcopfagus of King Pakal is an outstanding masterpiece found in the Temple of Inscriptions, and is a must-see for everyone interested in ancient mayan culture and art.
Tourist buses usually leave people at the upper entrance and pick them up at the lower one, by the museum. If you going by own car, there are parkings by both entrances, and an asphalt road connecting those. No water/food selling in the area, so take your own water-supply with you.

464564551.name: One of the most beautiful ruins
464564551.author: a TripAdvisor user
464564551.reviewBody:
Visited early morning. The ruins at the beginning had a beautiful layer of fog which cleared quickly. 
The ruins are partially covered in dense jungle, with only a small percentage being uncovered so far. 
There are heaps of tourists here (for good reason) so I recommend getting in early for easy climbing and to get some good photos. We had an amazing guide, although I can't remember his name (maybe Francisco?), and also did the guided jungle tour. Both were at additional cost but well worth it - the guide was able to tell us about all the history of the ruins and the surrounding environment. 
Simply a breathtaking part of the world, and really unique ruins. If ruins, archaeology, anthropology, history and culture are your thing... make the journey. And the views are amazing if your knees can bare all the stairs !!

463954489.name: Unmissable. Possibly the best preserved ruins in Mexico.
463954489.author: a TripAdvisor user
463954489.reviewBody: These ruins are in the middle of the jungle and you may well visit them accompanied by the sound of howler monkeys in the jungle. My nephew, an archaeologist, suggested we add this to our Mexican itinerary and I am so glad we did.\n\nTake water, sunhat and wear good trainer/walking shoes, and employ a local guide available outside.

463759506.name: Visting Palenque ruins
463759506.author: a TripAdvisor user
463759506.reviewBody: We took a tour from San Cristobal de las Casas to Palenque arriving in the afternoon after stops in Agua Azul and Miho Sol (waterfall).  We hired a spanish speaking tour guide at the entrance to the site, who took a small group of us (4 people) around the main parts of the ruins and told us the timeline and significance of the site. (this cost avout $5 each for an hour long tour). This was very worthwhile as the guide was very knowledgable and from the area.  The site is very impressive (there is no point in comparing site) and he said it was the 3rd most important site in the Mayan world.  It is very worthehile to learn a little but about the site before you get there to appreciate what you are seeing and questions you may have.It was also good to wander around the larger site (not just the main buidlings) but I would recommend going in the morning when it is cooler.

463578353.name: Very interesting site.....just as good as Chichen Itza
463578353.author: a TripAdvisor user
463578353.reviewBody:
We spent a morning visiting the site with a great local guide (Mildred). She was very informative and showed us around this amazing place.    You can visit without a guide, but you would miss so much.  It is a large site and only 10% has been uncovered so far. 

The museum afterwards was also very good and gave a complete picture of what is known so far.

Tip -  visit in the cooler parts of the day, i.e. Early morning is best,   Before the crowds and the heat arrive.

463343250.name: THE BEST RUINS!!!
463343250.author: a TripAdvisor user
463343250.reviewBody: We hired Maragarito (we met him at the front entrance with his son), and he did a jungle and pyramid tour. Very knowledgable. We think the best way to do this is with a tour guide, as the signs don\'t teach you much. Best pyramids ever!

463064041.name: Most beautiful Mayan ruins....
463064041.author: a TripAdvisor user
463064041.reviewBody: Highly recommend !! A must see in paleque.  Go in the morning if possible ... Takes about 3 hours to see everything.

462467176.name: Wonderful!!
462467176.author: a TripAdvisor user
462467176.reviewBody: This place doesn\'t feel as big as Uxmal or Tikal in Guatemala, but that\'s mainly because only a small part has been uncovered. But it\'s absolutely worth a visit!!

462338242.name: Spectacular Mayan Ruins & Pakal Tomb
462338242.author: a TripAdvisor user
462338242.reviewBody: Pyramids with a difference. Mayans who lived here built a site flourished 700-800 AD. The site is characterized by Mayan Chennes Architecture that includes Frieze-like borders of long rows of short, adjoining columns ca. 3\' high. Also characterized by two towers flanking the front and in some cases three, with the middle one set behind on back side of pyramid. The whole site is dedicated to the underworld. Palak, King who died ca 700, is buried beneath one of the pyramids which is his mausoleum. Palak\'s tomb\'s sarcophagus is one of the best preserved of all Mayan carvings and inscriptions. In the rear  of the main pyramid there is even a miniature ball court for royals to enjoy in afterlife.  Those who want can climb ruins. Spectacular site and unlike Chichen Etza is not crowded. (We visited both on weekdays.)

462333431.name: Great historical place
462333431.author: a TripAdvisor user
462333431.reviewBody: A lot of culture in the place! Great to meet with family and friends. I suggest a guide in the ruins so he/she can describe the history.

462105946.name: An amazing outing that is a bargain, easy to navigate and meets all expectations
462105946.author: a TripAdvisor user
462105946.reviewBody:
There are two fees to enter Palenque; one for the park, the other for the ruins. $5 in total and a bargain.
The place is well sign posted so no need for a guide (also $2 collectivos USD) run from town to the ruins so, again, a tour is a huge waste of cash.
Indescribable. We saved the palacio for last and covered the less visited northern section first. We climbed most of the ruins, walked seldom used passageways and arrived when the morning must made it even more magical. 
Advice: take the exit to the museum and see the cascades, suspension bridge and minir ruins in the jungle. Listen to the roar of monkeys! The museum is worth it to give context and is free with park admission.  Bring food and snacks.

462038356.name: Wonderful setting and beautiful carvings.
462038356.author: a TripAdvisor user
462038356.reviewBody:
Palenque is one of my favorite ruins in Mexico.  The setting is just gorgeous and being there really makes me wonder why the crowds are all at Chichen Itza... Oh wait, Chichen is close to Cancun, that is why. 

The wandering trails, river, beautiful canopy and other foliage, the monkeys all over the place, and striking carvings really make this a well-worth-it adventure.  We drove, which was easy enough from Palenque town, but was a little confusing on how to do things.  Just go to the very end of the road and try to park.  People asked us for money to watch our car, we refused.  I did give a little money to a very friendly boy who helped us back the car out later though... he didn't ask for it and seemed surprised.  In fact everyone there seemed friendly.  That made me think that it isn't really dangerous to park there - just maybe some guys take advantage of nervous nature to try to get extra cash.

Tickets are purchased across the street from the tiny lot in a seemingly unmarked building.  Then you walk up the street to what seems to be the end of the road for the entrance.

If you are nervous about navigating the entry alone, or don't have a car, get transport from Palenque town.  It is affordable and easy. 

There is a friendly tourist office inside Hotel Maya Tulipanes that is affordable and open to the public.  We also booked a trip to Yaxchilan through them and were quite pleased at not just the service, but also the prices compared to booking online.

461445765.name: The best site on our trip.....
461445765.author: a TripAdvisor user
461445765.reviewBody: ......visiting several historic sites around Mexico. We only touched on the sites over the two weeks, but there is certainly something about Palenque, with a real positivity and electricity to it, the whole site feeling alive! We arrived reasonably early before the main crowds which is worthwhile as you get lots of views and photos with few or no people in them. It is worthwhile going into the tomb with the covered entrance so as to see the original colours. If you can manage it please climb every set of steps to the top as you are rewarded with fantastic views over the site, in total 15sq km. A small word of warning if you investigate the temple with the tall tower try to avoid standing under the bats as they may make you welcome. As with others we had our excellent guide which makes the visit so much more interesting. Do come the \'jungle\', longer way back as this lets you see unrestored ruins and some interesting trees. Also leave some time to visit the museum at the end.

460874622.name: Magical Jungle Experience
460874622.author: a TripAdvisor user
460874622.reviewBody: Visiting the ruins is a definite must, but do not forget the surrounding jungle. Only 3% of the site is excavated, the rest lies shrouded in jungle foliage and mystery, exposing moss covered rock walls here, a tunnel there. While there is a main trail into the jungle for the tourists to walk the real adventure is when you hire a guide to take you away from that into the depths of the jungle herself. For this experience, if you speak either Spanish or Italian, I recommend you hire FIDENCIO, a Mayan guide from one of the near-by villages whose grandfather was a well known curandero - a native healer using medicinal plants -who shared his knowledge with his grandson. And Fidencio will share it with you. I have lived here now for four months, worked with many of the guides, and I can say UNEQUIVOCALLY that FIDENCIO is the best one. And if it\'s a hot day ask to be taken to one of the waterfalls buried deep in the jungle to be refreshed. Magic awaits!

460760183.name: Bucket List site!  Well worth the long trip.
460760183.author: a TripAdvisor user
460760183.reviewBody: The amazing and very important Mayan ruins at Palenque are open for business in the now-safe Chiapas State.  Infrastructure in the area is positively booming, with new hotels, restaurants, roads, sidewalks, etc.  Hire a guide; don\'t just walk around aimlessly.  The certified guides are excellent.  I strongly recommend reading up on the Maya before you go.  Unfortunately, the place is crawling with vendors every step you take, not just in the entrance/parking area,  Some of the handicrafts they sell are quite nice, and inexpensive, but you cannot escape them, and to me, it interfered with my communing with a thousand years of history.  Unlike at Chichen Itza, you can still climb the great pyramids at Palenque and it\'s very much worth doing for the spectacular view all the way to the Gulf of Mexico, 100 km (60 miles) away.  Palenque is huge but only 20% excavated so far.  Important: go in the morning, as early as you can, before it gets very hot.  I am so glad I visited Palenque.

460484100.name: Great!
460484100.author: a TripAdvisor user
460484100.reviewBody:
Great ruins well worth the detour of flying into Palenque then to San Cristobal rather than directly to Tuxla. When we visited there was not many people, which were nice. I also appreciated that you could walk around on several of the monuments - not everywhere, but in some places - which is a rare treat nowadays. It was fantastic to explore the internals of the palace. My 5-year old loved it!

Note that there are no coffee shops etc at the ruins, so do not expect a Starbucks break.

(There is  a jungle walk next door and a museum, which might be good if you have enough energy. We did not.

459998769.name: Amazing!
459998769.author: a TripAdvisor user
459998769.reviewBody: One of the best ruins in Mexico. You can get  a sence how did it look like in it\'s glory days. A lot of objects to visit and climb. Deffinetly worth the trip. And it\'s quite cheap compered to more famous ruins in Yucatan, only 70 persos (3.5 eur).

459177564.name: All you have ever read or seen
459177564.author: a TripAdvisor user
459177564.reviewBody: Will be bettered once you enter this magic place,but,come early in the day. I say early as you will be aware that this is one of the mostvisited sites in Mexico,but earlier you come the cooler it is and to watch the sun creeping out while the wild life warm up is an addition to the experience.\nWe have been waiting to visit this site for around thirty years,had to cancel once due to a cardiac problem but boy I am glad that we made it at last.

459043709.name: Beautiful
459043709.author: a TripAdvisor user
459043709.reviewBody: Quick Note: They charge to get on the road that leads to the ruins parking lot. Then they charge 70 pesos per person to actually go inside. Mexican citizens get in free on Sundays.

458988340.name: Recommend to Visit
458988340.author: a TripAdvisor user
458988340.reviewBody: We caught a collectivo from Palenque town for MXN20 pp.  Our guide Salvador Flores who we highly recommend we sourced at the entrance to the ruins. Salvador explained fully about the ruins in a 2 hour tour.

458949741.name: Great walk, no guide needed.
458949741.author: a TripAdvisor user
458949741.reviewBody:
We arrived on the local bus for 20pesos, then were greeted by many of the local young lads with offerings of magic mushrooms to our surprise....

We proceeded to take and unguided tour and found it easy to read all the information as it was in English. Beautiful place.

458397602.name: Verry great ruins
458397602.author: a TripAdvisor user
458397602.reviewBody:
The taxi collectivo to ruins cost 20MXN and also drive if it is not full so we did not have to wait long time.
The fee is verry good for what you can see. 32MXN for the park and another 70 for the ruins.
It is a verry big town with lots of buildings. Also sone building constructions were new to us though we visited 5 other ruins before. 
Only a bit disappointing was that you can't see the "astronout" anymore but most of other parts are open also for climbing on the ruins.
We were there about 5 hours for visit the ruins and buying some souvenirs (don't forgett to haggle to get them cheaper) 
Also it was verry easy finding a collectivo back to palenque.

458372282.name: Be prepared for lots of walking
458372282.author: a TripAdvisor user
458372282.reviewBody:
Amazing ruins that are well maintained. 
Be prepared to pay for entry and parking. 
And if you go with your own transport don't take the route to museo as that will give you 1.3km back to your car. There are lots of taxi/buses to take you back. 
Whilst very hot, there is s lot of shade.
Quite a few stairs. But not too bad

458348632.name: Breathtaking
458348632.author: a TripAdvisor user
458348632.reviewBody: Nothing I could write can truly describe this place. This is the type of place you visit and \'feel\' and it\'s feeling will stay with you and invade your thoughts and fire your imagination. It\'s a must at all costs see. A head for heights and sensible footwear will help you getting around .

458173102.name: Dripping with History and Culture
458173102.author: a TripAdvisor user
458173102.reviewBody: These ruins take you to a completely different world. The ingenuity of the Mayans and the thrilling history captivates the visitor. Getting a guide would be better to understand the significance of each part of the ruins. Be sure to haggle with them though. Get your best shoes, hats and sunscreen and be ready to climb up some ancient temples

458146542.name: A must see
458146542.author: a TripAdvisor user
458146542.reviewBody: Palenque is one of the must see Mayan ruins.  The buildings have been nicely restored and the grounds are very pleasant.  As with all of the Mayan sites it is best to get there early in the morning to avoid both the heat of the day and the crowds.

457560456.name: Well worth a visit!
457560456.author: a TripAdvisor user
457560456.reviewBody: We arrived around 11 am and I was surprised by the number of people already touring the ruins. Our group hired an English speaking guide. He provided good explanations of what we were looking at, and included time for photos. There was a lot of walking and stairs, and it was hot and humid. Be sure to take water. If you forget, you can buy some at the entrance. As with other ruins, vendors are out in full force here for all of your souvenir needs.

457310941.name: So well maintained, gorgeous jungle ruins
457310941.author: a TripAdvisor user
457310941.reviewBody: Palenque is the most impressive ruins of all! Do go when it opens at 8 am and expect to be walking and enjoying until noon at least! Go before hot and crowded! January and February are the best months for weather and fewer people.  Beautiful follage, howler monkeys, and if you are lucky some scarlet macaws over head. From town it is a. 20 peso collective ride to ruin as....32 pesos per person to enter the park and 70 pesos to enter the ruins .....bring your own water and snacks! Nice little Museum.....no longer any \ncafe.

457190412.name: Breathtaking and awe inspiring
457190412.author: a TripAdvisor user
457190412.reviewBody: This is one of the major classical Mayan sites and not to be missed  The city as magnificent as Chichen Itza and represents the height of classical Mayan culture,  as home to the great Mayan king Pakal .   The many temples and on-site museum not to be missed.

457011932.name: Great ruins, cheap and accessible
457011932.author: a TripAdvisor user
457011932.reviewBody:
Great site - we visited after seeing Yaxchilan, Tikal, Xunantunich and Cahal Pech, and it was totally still worth it. The site is big, well signed and notably different in style to the others. Some of the buildings have been restored, but very sensitively.  

If you're already in Palenque town, its super easy to reach - just head for the big roundabout by the ADO bus station and passing combis will stop for you within a few minutes (we got hailed before we even reached it). They only cost 20p each way, and with entrance to the park and ruin site a combined 100p, you can do the whole trip for a total of $7. Which is amazing. 

Also, don't worry too much about the site being too full - we went at 9am on a sunny Friday, stayed til around 12pm and had no trouble. Yes there are quite a few ppl there but its so big it never felt crowded, and the further you get from the main plaza, the quieter it gets. 

Lots of ppl seem to complain about the vendors, of which there are quite a few, but they were all perfectly polite and not pushy in the least. Didn't bother us at all!

456878253.name: It\'s worth the hassle
456878253.author: a TripAdvisor user
456878253.reviewBody:
If you're undecided, please check the many professional videos on youtube and you’ll see that it’s a must even if a diversion is required. 
The place is magic and mostly accessible (with the exception of Pakal’s pyramid), surrounded by jungle and close to waterfalls. The ruins are very well preserved and breath-taking with a lot of intact images.
Practicalities – don’t think to reach Palenque from S. Cristobal. A couple of friends had to give up after 4 hrs journey: strikers block the road and ask for money to let you pass thus the trip might last up to 8 hrs.
Villahermosa is a ugly town (with a very nice park museum ‘Las Velas’) but it’s the best gateway to Palenque (2.5hrs by bus ADO). Also mind that the museum is closed on Monday (and it’s a must).

456562395.name: Spectacular Mayan archaeological site
456562395.author: a TripAdvisor user
456562395.reviewBody: Well worth a full day, including visiting the Museum.\nOne of the best preserved and accessible Mayan site. Many of the buildings may be climbed, which is unusual, and several of the burial chambers can be entered.

456442554.name: Prefer Tikal
456442554.author: a TripAdvisor user
456442554.reviewBody: Worth it for those really into runes however disappointment if to have any vendors on site especially ones who play imitation wildlife sounds and spoil the jungle experience for many.

456043876.name: Hard to get to but worth it
456043876.author: a TripAdvisor user
456043876.reviewBody: Went as part of G Adventures tour. Huge, many buildings, get a guide to explain everything, bring hat, sunscreen, water but lots of trees for shade.

456041894.name: You will be amazed
456041894.author: a TripAdvisor user
456041894.reviewBody: Unfortunately our day tour arrived late, 3:45 and park closes at 5. As soon as you walk in you immediately feel an energy wave from this beautiful place. Yes your\'e not allowed to climb most of the ruins but you can still admire the beauty from below. You are allowed to climb the highest ruin which you can overlook the whole park. Was a great place to enjoy the ruins, rainforest, exotic animals and weather. There are may vendors so make sure you shop around for prices. There are also many tour guides at the entrance, unfortunately our tour guide sucked and gave more opinion than actual facts so make sure you do some reading before you go. There is A LOT of climbing if you want the best experience so make sure your\'e somewhat active before visiting and take plenty of water and sun block. Also, closing time is actually 4:45 so arrive with plenty of time.

456009702.name: Great place to visit
456009702.author: a TripAdvisor user
456009702.reviewBody: This mayan site is world famous, so it\'s worth of visit. It\'s well organised - clean and with mayan people selling souvenirs.

455978634.name: excellent site
455978634.author: a TripAdvisor user
455978634.reviewBody: after visiting Copan, Tikal & Yaxha we were stunned by the Palenque ruins. very different o the other sites, well maintained and easy to explore.

455737944.name: Impressive
455737944.author: a TripAdvisor user
455737944.reviewBody: We hired a guide at the ruins which really brought to life what we were seeing. It is impressive to see how many pyramids have been found and how many more are still covered by the jungle. The guides at Palenque ruins are very knowledgeable and worth the price. We paid the equivalence of US$50 for a 1 hour tour for 3 people. It is an absolutely amazing site!

455733153.name: don\'t go there in the afternoon
455733153.author: a TripAdvisor user
455733153.reviewBody: We went there in the afternoon. My boyfriend and me are not the biggest fans of ruins since we already saw many in Mexico. But many travellers told us, that the ones in Palenque should be nice, because of the environment. We got a ticket at 4pm. The ruins ae opened until 5pm, there are lots of signs saying that. The ruins are nice, but not well maintained. The environment makes in beautiful. It is nice that you can go into some ruins and climb on some. However, at 4:30 an unfriendly guard told us, that we have to leave now. We just wanted to visit one more pyramid, but he shouted at us, telling us, that this part is already closed. He was really rude and asked for our tickets. We wanted to show us, that there is the information on the tickets that it is closing at 4:45 but there was no information on our tickets. I never met such an unfriendly person in Mexico. All of the staff oder there were so pushing and rude, shouting at the visitors. I have no idea why. So we had no other choice then leaving the ruins after 35 minutes...definitely not worth the 70 pesos we paid.

455673484.name: My Favorite Mayan Ruins
455673484.author: a TripAdvisor user
455673484.reviewBody:
These ruins are magical!
Walking through dense ´jungle´and getting a glimpse of the ruins was fantastic, especially after having been to Chitzen Itza.
We arrived early via a private transfer from the town of Palenque, although it is easy and cheap to catch a collectivo from the main round-about with the large Mayan statue. The bus will display Ruinas/or Pyramides. (from memory it was about 20 pesos).
As with all Mayan ruins it pays to arrive early to avoid crowds.
Our guide at the ruins was Francisco, and he was superb. He was clearly very passionate about the site and was a wealth of information. We met him at the first tent near the main building.
The ruins which have been excavated are in good condition. There were not many signs to explain the ruins, and we saw many people carrying guide books around to work their way through the site, but having a guide will help understand the Mayan history as well as the significance of the site.
What i enjoyed most about these ruins was the mystery associated with them and that there is so much to be discovered.
Once we finished our exploration around the main site, we were able to hire Francisco for more guiding outside of the main temple complex and discover more hidden and un-excavated ruins. Walking through the jungle knowing that underneath your feet could be more significant ruins was wonderful.
Some of the ruins you are able to climb up, although they are slippery so take care.
The site ticket includes entrance to the museum at the bottom of the site.
It is worth taking a look, however after walking around the ruins for some hours we found it a bit underwhelming and a lot of information to take on in one day.

455322670.name: Do It Yourself Explanation
455322670.author: a TripAdvisor user
455322670.reviewBody:
This is a review based from Palenquè town.  If you are staying in Palenquè,  there are many tour operators that offer package trips to the ruins, as well as a short visit to other attractions in the area.  If you're short on time, this may well be your best bet,  but also the most expensive. This is the DIY option.  Beware!  We met a group that grossly overpaid for a private van and tour of the ruins, (350p per person) only to find out that their payment only covered the transport costs.  A collectivo costs 20p one way, plus 30p national park fee, plus 70p ruins entrance.   A decent, authorized tour guide will cost you between 1500p and 2500p, on top of your park entry fee (30p) and your Ruins entry fee (70p).  NOTA BENE: The museum entry fee is included in your Ruins entry fee, yet the museum is closed on Mondays.
     So back to the original point; if you want to get there yourself, simply go to the ADO station and you'll see the highway signs that direct traffic towards RUINAS PALENQUÈ.   Either wait there until you see a collectivo with a sign in the windshield marked "Palenque" and wave them down, or start walking down that road and they will undoubtedly honk at you as they pass. 
    Alternatively, walk towards Palenquè Centro and you can find a few collectivos waiting to fill up for the short 9km trip.(20p) Once you've made it there, you will be aproached by several guides,  whom I've actually watched flip a coin to see who gets the next tourist.  If you're  going to spend the money, step aside and have a drink of water, and don't just accept the first guide that strong arms you as you leave your bus.  Like I said, they are not cheap, make sure you're getting your money's worth.
