After our tour we took the 40 minute walk to the museum. The path wanders through the jungle past waterfalls and partially excavated temples and residences. The museum is well done and contains many of the original artifacts unearthed at the site. Palenque was much less crowded than Chichen Itza and the vendors were much less intrusive. However visitor amenities like cafes are much less developed. This site is well worth a visit.

254481474.name: Wow
254481474.author: a TripAdvisor user
254481474.reviewBody: This site is a must see, not overly crowded like Chichen Itza, hire a guide, the complex is just magnificent, extremely large and only a portion is explored. The guide cost $1000 pesos about $70 US, for 4 people and a tour of over 2 1/2 hours. He was Mayan and offered many insights into not only the ruins, but the environment and life in the area.

254311512.name: A must but...
254311512.author: a TripAdvisor user
254311512.reviewBody: For those who are interested in Mayan cities, Palenque is a must. I\'ve visited lots of sites (Chichen, Uxmal, Maya Pan, Izamal, Dzibilchaltun to name a few and Palenque is at the top of my liste. But you must be aware that if you\'re staying in San Cristobal de las Casa like we did and decide to go on a tour, packages also include a visit at Agua Azul and Misol Ha. No direct Palaenque tour exists at the present moment. It\'s a 17-18 hour back and forth bumpy ride on a small collectivo type bus with a one hour stop for breakfest where you have to wait for the very few who eat in a restaurant serving food I wouldn\'t let my dog eat. You have 5 hours at most to visit these 3 places. The tour guide won\'t even mention the Palenque site Museum because you won\'t have time to visit it. To visit the Palenque site you\'ll have to walk very fast to see places the site guides won\'t show you!!  I wouldn\'t recommend renting a car in San Crsitobal de las Casas to visit the site because on your way there\'s a 99% chance zapatistas will block the way and force you to pay a \'ransom-tax\' before letting you pass through. It\'s better to visit it from Villahermosa, only 2 hours away without zapatistas or spend a couple of days in one of the many hotels close of the site.

254199390.name: Still amazing
254199390.author: a TripAdvisor user
254199390.reviewBody: We were there 25 years ago and were overwhelmed. Coming back we were a little bit nervous whether we still would enjoy it as much as the first time. The good news is it is still great even when today are many more tourists. We were relatively lucky because we were there later in the afternoon and not too many people were there.

254126850.name: Great Mayan Site
254126850.author: a TripAdvisor user
254126850.reviewBody: I went to Palenque straight from my flight into Cancun and it was definitely worth the 12 hour overnight trip. I arrived in town early so I was able to get to the ruins while it was still cool and there were no tour groups, just some Mexicans and solo travellers. The ruins are fantastic and as the site is not too big you can spend plenty of time at each structure without having to give up a day. This might change one day if they bother to excavate the rest of the buildings.\n\nEach structure has a small description giving an overview of what it was used for. I was satisfied with is having read about the site prior to my visit however a guide would offer more info if your the type of person who likes more knowledge on the site or do not know too much before going. You can climb up each structure which is nice and gives good views over the entire place. There are vendors selling items inside the site but these were low in numbers at the time of my visit. I can image there being more later in the day when the tour groups arrive.

253615899.name: Like something from an Indianna Jones film set
253615899.author: a TripAdvisor user
253615899.reviewBody: These ruins set in the jungle and are absolutely a must see. They are so atmospheric and amazing. Either read up about them before you go or get a guide to take you around.. The waterfall which can be passed on the way out is some place you would imagine in a film set . It can  get hot so take water. Good footwear is essential as there is a lot of narrow steps to climb up and down.

253583811.name: Best Mayan ruins in Mexico!
253583811.author: a TripAdvisor user
253583811.reviewBody: Beautiful area.  Loved the museum.  I would do the museum first before the park and you wouldn\'t need a guide because the museum teaches you everything.

253551704.name: More Than Expected
253551704.author: a TripAdvisor user
253551704.reviewBody: We enjoyed the Palenque Jungle and Ruins way more than we expected.  The ruins cover a vast area of land and, with the right guide, you can be brought back to Mayan times when the ruins were inhabited (~500 AD) and imagine the lifestyle.  We believe that a guide is very important to understand the history and get the richest experience out of the visit.  Guides are available before entering the ruins.

253389198.name: Incredible Mayan ruins
253389198.author: a TripAdvisor user
253389198.reviewBody: The mystical atmosphere of these ruins help you imagine they were inhabited for almost a thousand years, over a thousand years ago.

253266350.name: ruins at palenque
253266350.author: a TripAdvisor user
253266350.reviewBody: Very well maintained roads and grounds, easy to find, and majestic ruins to explore. The children selling souvenirs were delightful!

252952998.name: May be the best of the Mayan ruinas
252952998.author: a TripAdvisor user
252952998.reviewBody: I have now been at Tikal, Qirigua, Copan, Chichen Itza, Uzmal, Dzibilchaltun, Ek Balam, Tulum, Kohunich, Yaxchalan, Bonampak and Palenque.  Palenque may be the biggest and best of the sites.  Spectacular buildings, setting and artwork all on the one site.  The museum, like so many Mexican regional museums, is not as well maintained as it should be considering the works it houses.  Lights out so that it was not possible to read signs etc.  However, the holdings are excellent.

252447909.name: Beautiful Mayan Ruins
252447909.author: a TripAdvisor user
252447909.reviewBody: Palenque ruins are set in a beautiful park-like environment, surely the most beautiful spot of any of the Mayan ruins. Allow plenty of time for a thorough contemplation of the buildings, especially the palace with it\'s beautiful carvings. The atmosphere of the whole park is languid and lovely. The only missing piece was the lack of a cafe in the visitor center. Don\'t miss the museum in the visitor center with the most amazing sarcophagus ever!

251716549.name: amazing walk in the past, very well taken care of
251716549.author: a TripAdvisor user
251716549.reviewBody: we found a local private guide, who was Mayan and spoke his native tongue, which we felt was very important, lots of charismatic non native guides that i would avoid, bargain with the tour price if you havent already prebooked it. take a cheap and safe collectivo ride to the ruins from Palenque for about 20 pesos a person, they run all the time! We were taken back to the past with such an amazing oratory description of the tomb of the red queen, Pakals tomb, the temple of the dead, this was a real history lesson, our family of four were all captivated, we did not hear a complaint!

251713575.name: amazing ruins, go in the jungle!! bring good shoes
251713575.author: a TripAdvisor user
251713575.reviewBody: we found a guide there, I worked out a cheaper price than offered and said i would tip as well, this seems to help when locking in a price, dont take the first one that comes along and let them wait a bit so you can think about it and talk it over with your group. we went with a certified guide who pays a monthly fee to the park, we were very pleased, the grounds are amazingly kept and lots of markers and descriptions if you dont want a guide, but if you can afford it, we paid 800 pesos (60 us)for a big tour of the amazing ruins,you can still climb the red queens tomb and another amazing pyramid that offers a beyond compare vista and the jungle which took 4 hours we were told about so much and the tour in the jungle was amazing, we saw and heard howler monkeys(rare), learned about so many medicinal Mayan plants and so many jungle ruins,2% of the Palenque ruins are excavated and the rest is protected! and saw the ancient water springs that  the Mayans drank from! so did I! you are not allowed in the jungle or too much of it anyhow, unless witha  guide and i would really really rally for that!  enjoy and good adventuring

251567901.name: Ruins
251567901.author: a TripAdvisor user
251567901.reviewBody: Incredible sites with good guides if you look, don\'t go for the first guide that offers services. try to get an individual guide to walk the sites at your own pace. There are "colectivos" that will charge you $20 (twenty pesos) about $1.50 Can to take you to the ruins. the same amount will be charged to bring you back.

251202292.name: rainy and gorgeous
251202292.author: a TripAdvisor user
251202292.reviewBody: set in the middle of the forest, only about 10-20% of the total ruins have been excavated. it rains there( we were there in june) so carry umbrellas, a torch and good shoes. not many monuments can be climbed but there are some places where you can walk around. the architecture is amazing. watch for the detail. beautiful vistas so a good camera is a must. many carvings have been walled up because they were naked specially of beautiful women. the entry fee is totally worth it but you must get a good guide who knows the place and does not give you the official sanitized version. the mexican government does not allow foreign archaeologists freely as they have their own "official version" of the history of the place. erich von daniken anyone?? but its a must see. visit the museum too not too far away.

251181501.name: Great Place \u00a1\u00a1\u00a1
251181501.author: a TripAdvisor user
251181501.reviewBody: You will enter a different world sorrounded by ruins in very good shape, and you can also go to the top of them to appreciate the landscape, it is a lifetime experience.

251132674.name: one of the best!
251132674.author: a TripAdvisor user
251132674.reviewBody: I visited many ruins, and Palenque and Uxmal stand among the best! Palenque has the added differential of being in a forest - it is recommended to bring a raincoat, it rains a lot. There is also an ecological trail in the forest.

250747122.name: Linger until the crowds are gone
250747122.author: a TripAdvisor user
250747122.reviewBody: The buildings here are visually stunning and there is plenty to see. Note that there is plenty of drinks being sold and most of it not quite cold enough but food offerings are scarce. The forest setting makes for a restful experience and there are plenty of shady places to sit and enjoy the views. Its 28 pesos entry to the park and 59 pesos to the ruins. Don\'t get sucked into getting the first guide that comes along and tells you he\'s the official one.guide. We paid 1200 pesos who did not take us to all the temples and didn\'t add a lot of value. There are some at 800 and 950 who could be better value. Most people rattled through pretty quick and we found we had the place to ourselves around lunchtime. After looking at the main ruins we followed some of the jungle paths and reached a work area where archaeologists were busy excavating out a swimming pool that had been part of the city complex. Amazing! We would love to go back in the future to see what has been finally unearthed!.

250507489.name: Preclassic to Classic-era ruins, must-see!
250507489.author: a TripAdvisor user
250507489.reviewBody: Extensive ruins of an important Classic-era Mayan city-state from 200-900 CE. Well-curated & -interpreted museum includes Pakal\'s actual sarcophagus & an excellent reproduction of his burial chamber, illustrated in etched lucite/plexiglass.

250241078.name: Excellent!
250241078.author: a TripAdvisor user
250241078.reviewBody: This is a definitely site to see! I liked it as it was on the middle of the jungle. You should get their as early as you can in order to avoid crowds. Guides are available. Enjoy!

250159304.name: Beautiful even in the rain an excellent day
250159304.author: a TripAdvisor user
250159304.reviewBody: These are  some really amazing ruinas even if you end up visiting in the rain. And the location they are set in is equally breath taking.

249999766.name: Highlight of the area
249999766.author: a TripAdvisor user
249999766.reviewBody: In spite of the crowds and vendors, there is always a thrill to be on the grounds and seeing these spectacular ruins.  Birding on the grounds is not what it was years ago, but you can still find some spots on the fringes to spot bords.

249836662.name: Breathtaking
249836662.author: a TripAdvisor user
249836662.reviewBody:
The best place we saw in Mexico. 

Getting a guided tour of Palenque is a must, our guide (Naxto) couldn't have been better. He took us over the ruins talked us through everything from the bed chambers to the steam rooms. We then went on a walk through the jungle to see other ruins still buried and 'claimed' by the jungle

A place we'll never forget. Far less over crowded than the chichen itza (easily 100 times less people there) and you're able to climb on the ruins and even go inside the tomb of Pakal

249359377.name: Amazing
249359377.author: a TripAdvisor user
249359377.reviewBody: Visited this ruin with a guide book and lots of research on our own. Allow at least 3 -4 hours to visit plus 1 hour for the Museo 1 km down the road.

249033203.name: A complete visit
249033203.author: a TripAdvisor user
249033203.reviewBody: Palenque is the most beautiful and complete place of the Maia civilization I had visited in Mexico. Read about Pakal before. We saw a really nice play at the theatre in San Cristobal de las Casas. Don\'t miss the morning tour over throw the jungle where you can see the unexplored city, the swimming pools, and the Forgotten Templo. After finish your tour, walk to the museum and take the transport service back to the town by 20 pesos.

248175118.name: Some of the best
248175118.author: a TripAdvisor user
248175118.reviewBody: I have seen many, many mayan ruins in Mexico and Guatemala and Palenque is one of my favorites. You can go inside some of the ruins, which is rare, and there is some unique architecture. Love it.

248174802.name: Best Maya Ruins
248174802.author: a TripAdvisor user
248174802.reviewBody: I have been to almost all the Maya ruins in Mexico, as well as in Belize and Guatemala.  I rate Palenque as the most beautiful.  This was my second visit and I loved it just as much as the first.  The thing that makes it special is the setting:  The lush, green, jungle mountain. The serenity in palpable.  Not to be missed.

248157899.name: Get an official guide- Jose Luis is your man!
248157899.author: a TripAdvisor user
248157899.reviewBody: We really enjoyed our first few hours wandering Palenque on our own, but on our second visit we decided to go with a guide. Jose Luis (the only official guide called Jose) offered to show us a different side of the ruins, the temples & houses hidden in the jungle, & we were not disappointed! Jose has an incredible knowledge of the plants, animals, architecture, history & customs of the area, & has an excellent sense of humour. It\'s easy to be impressed by the ruins at Palenque but Jose really opened our eyes to just how unbelievably advanced the Mayans were. We weren\'t sure if a second visit was needed but I\'m so so glad we went back & went into the jungle with an official guide. Jose is a champion!

247555753.name: Great historical place with special energy
247555753.author: a TripAdvisor user
247555753.reviewBody: A great place to visit, lots of history. And yes, you can feel the ancient energy. All well kept and still in the progress of restoration. Unfortunately groups of Mexican tourists think they are in a soccer stadium and keep cheering all the time, which really is disturbing in such a sacred place. Don\'t forget to do a private jungle tour with a local guide!

246849943.name: The best ruins we saw in Mexico
246849943.author: a TripAdvisor user
246849943.reviewBody: During our trip we visited Tulum, Palenque and Chichen Itza. Palenque was by far the best. For starters, you can actually walk on the ruins and really feel like you\'re back in Mayan times. The stroll down through the jungle temples is great. It also feels much more authentic that the bigger tourist traps - the guides and vendors are from the nearby local villages, you get the feeling this place really means something to them.\nWe took a guide who gave us a 1 hour jungle tour and then 1 hour tour of the ruins. Well worth it for all the little nuggets of insight, but make sure you negotiate on the price.

246744694.name: A Special Set of Ruins Not To Be Missed
246744694.author: a TripAdvisor user
246744694.reviewBody: You can climb most of the temples to see the great carvings and fading drawings. The howler monkeys can be heard in the distance. A perfect site that you can cover in two or three hours. Beautiful scenery in the rain forest. Don\'t miss these ruins.

246675624.name: Amazing place
246675624.author: a TripAdvisor user
246675624.reviewBody: Probably the best ruins I saw in Mexico. Plenty of opportunities get get momentos and whoth climbing up some of the ruins (suprising that this is open to such activities) to get the views from the top. An amazing site and an excellent days viewing.

246265055.name: One of the best archeological sites in Mexico
246265055.author: a TripAdvisor user
246265055.reviewBody: Beautiful Maya ruins in the middle of the jungle , will be better if u have a guide to understand more , nice museum. Bad part  a lots of street vendors

246107655.name: top archeological site
246107655.author: a TripAdvisor user
246107655.reviewBody: This is possibly my favourite archeological site in Mexico. I have seen many, but this is so deep in the nature that it always surprises me. Totally worth visiting!

245874835.name: One of the musts when you travel the world
245874835.author: a TripAdvisor user
245874835.reviewBody: Without doubt Palenque is one of the musts that every world traveller should include in his plans. Set in a beautiful jungle environment this place lets your mind wander freely and puts yourself into that Mayan period of  mysticism, religious devotion, permanent wars and cruel sacrifices. Although it lacks that special atmosphere of the Peruvian Machu Picchu (my favourite arqueological site which everyone should have seen in his lifetime) it still conveys something that you will never forget.\nLook for a good guide who has some knowlegde of all the Mayan traditions and speaks Maya-Chol, and the time of the Red Queen and Pacal will become a vivid and lasting memory.

245550334.name: OMG ..............
245550334.author: a TripAdvisor user
245550334.reviewBody:
We spent a full day here soaking in the power and sites of Palenque Ruinas. Truely Amazing. 

We did a self-guided tour because I have some previous knowledge of the Ruins. On this subject; its up to you if you take a tour guide. If you are totally ignorant of the ruins; then definitely get one  $40.00 US - you will need to know some facts to truely understand Palenque. If you know a bit of Mayan history and Palenque - then get the guide book for $10 from the vendors.

You can climb a few of the temples; but not the Temple of Inscriptions. Which was very dis-appointing. There are others that you can and it is definitely worth the hike up. Some are not the hard.

No food or drink sold on site. Just from vendors beforehand. 

I totally totally recommend Palenque Ruinas.

244083651.name: So glad we got a chance to see this
244083651.author: a TripAdvisor user
244083651.reviewBody: The ruins themselves are magnificent but their situation in the surrounding jungle made them even more special.  It was easy to imagine that there were still so many other structures still covered by the jungle. The surrounding gardens and walk to the museum was very pretty.  We spent the better part of a day between the ruins and the museum and gardens.

243269072.name: Worth seeing
243269072.author: a TripAdvisor user
243269072.reviewBody: The Palenque ruins are a must see.  Set amongst the lush green jungle these ruins are one of the most important Mayan cities of ancient Mexico. The ruins are quite well preserved and you can climb to the top of one pyramid for spectacular views over the ruins and the jungle.  The area is prone to sudden downpours so be prepared with a rain jacket and insect repellent for mosquitoes.

243059335.name: Allow plenty of time. Set in lovely parkland
243059335.author: a TripAdvisor user
243059335.reviewBody: This is my fifth Mayan site, but I am a poor student of history. The site is one of the bigger ones and there are some architectural masterpieces, which are well documented. The site is beautifully laid out in parkland, with ample places to sit and admire. \nThe whole place feels less immersed in jungle than many of the other sites, but that is precisely what I liked about those ones!\n(For sheer Indiana Jones factor, Yaxchilan is amazing)

242683981.name: lost city
242683981.author: a TripAdvisor user
242683981.reviewBody: Unique atmosphere of Mayan town placed in the jungle. Morning after rain was beautiful with all that fog slowly uncovering trees and ruins in early sun. One can allmost  feel the great history of that Mayan place...

242120640.name: An absolute must see
242120640.author: a TripAdvisor user
242120640.reviewBody:
When in Mexico, go southwest to a UNESCO World Heritage Site that dates  back to 226 BC. 
First you must get there. Fly into Tuxtla Gutierrez in Chiapas state. There are a lot of things to see on day trips from there. Take the time to visit some of them. Then book a visit to Palenque and my suggestion would be via bus with an overnight stay as it is a LONG ride.
When you get there, find a guide if you do not already have one; and take your time visiting all of the temples, climbing the many stairs and going inside those that you can. You should plan on spending several hours taking it all in and using your camera to its fullest.
As a footnote,let me just say that Palenque and many other sites in Mexico will give other ruins around the world a run for their money.

241880732.name: Mayan Magnificence
241880732.author: a TripAdvisor user
241880732.reviewBody: An interesting site in extensive park and woodland. Be prepared for some steep climbs to fully appreciate it.

241186979.name: Great!
241186979.author: a TripAdvisor user
241186979.reviewBody: Beautifull ru\u00efnes in an impressive surrouding. You are really in \u00e0 tropical forest with \u00e0 beatifull cascade.\nYou have to visit this when you are around.

241124142.name: Fantastic Maya Ruins in the forest
241124142.author: a TripAdvisor user
241124142.reviewBody: I went to the Palenque ruins with a friend on a three week trip through Mexico, and these ruins were a highlight of the tour. What makes them special in my eyes is that they are right integrated in the surrounding forest/national park, and that they cover quite a big area. \n\nIf you go there, I\'d recommend you to go by yourself (car, bike, colectivo, taxi) unless you book a combined tour (p.e. combined with Misol-H\u00e1 and Aqua Azules where it is hard to go by yourself), that is because the tour is doing nothing else then just the transport and the ruins are quite close to the city of Palenque. Unlike Tulum or Chichen-Itza, where they try to sell you insect repellent even so there are just very few Mosquitoes (that at least happened to me), in Palenque you might really need to bring some repellent, not just for the ruins but also for your stay in the city.

241033494.name: The best! Much better than Chich\u00e9n Itz\u00e1
241033494.author: a TripAdvisor user
241033494.reviewBody:
The ruins are AMAZING! 
First - the location, the ruins are located in a jungle forest and blend with the enviroment, this is amazing to look at. You can also climb on them and walk around freely. There are also just "raw" ruins in the jungle that are not the main attraction but are still amazing. There's also a river running arround in the middle of the ruins with several small waterfalls, real beauty. 

Second - the site is less comersialized than Chichén Itzá, less vendors and other stuff. 

This place is a MUST

240723214.name: Blown away!
240723214.author: a TripAdvisor user
240723214.reviewBody: We were completely blown away by the beauty of the Palenque ruins.  This place had more of a wow factor for us than Chichen Itza.  The entry fee was only 59 pesos I think and make sure to come early as it gets so hot and humid around lunch time.  The whole scene is set here, you are in the middle of the jungle and can hear howler monkeys all around you!  We spent about 3 - 4 hrs here and could have spent more.  It is so expansive, there is a lot to see.  The climbing up and down of the pyramids can be hard on the knees but it\'s worth the effort.  Make sure you exit at the trail that also takes you to the museum.  Amazing side paths with more ruins and hardly any people.  A lot of stairs to climb but again it\'s worth it!  There\'s also a gorgeous waterfall at the end.  Spectacular.  Bring water, sunscreen, hat and mosquito repellent.

240715983.name: ANOTHER IMPRESSING MAYA CULTURE
240715983.author: a TripAdvisor user
240715983.reviewBody: although we have visited most of the maya sites in mexico guatemala and honduras, and although we have seen more dramatic and better restored site,palenque is very impressing archeological site, which is a must see for those who appreciate cultures traditions and art.\ndon\'t miss the museum which is about 1.5 mile from the gate UPHILL, and walking from the museum to the parking lot is not easy for old folks like myself (70), so either take care to be picked up, or have patience, and wait for a collectivo.

240399587.name: Outstanding Mayan Ruins
240399587.author: a TripAdvisor user
240399587.reviewBody: This is a very developed and well kept site.  But there are street vendors everywhere in the site itself ,not just at the entrance, and that spoils the ambiance.  Take the time to explore the smaller pyramids off on the side plazas. They are a welcome respite from the crowds.  Also walk down the waterfall path to the museum.  The path is a long series of stairs so it can be hard on the knees but it is worth it. The museum itself is wonderful, filled with incredibly detailed artifacts and carvings and plaster figures, and the sarcophagus of the Red Queen.  Very cool!

240312167.name: breathtaking
240312167.author: a TripAdvisor user
240312167.reviewBody: there are many ruins and you can still clim them!  Tour guides are outside and very helpful.  recommend to go early as it gets very humid

240017892.name: More than we expected
240017892.author: a TripAdvisor user
240017892.reviewBody: When we planned our recent trip we expected Chichen Itza to be the site that would blow us away, well it turned out Palanque is more expansive and gave us a much better feel for how people really lived. Site is in great condition and is continuing to be restored. Should have allocated 2 full days.

239511969.name: amazing
239511969.author: a TripAdvisor user
239511969.reviewBody: two days just walk around and around, go the forest behind the ruins up the hills and back, did not wanna go home. Yes its amazing

239150159.name: Too much people on one place
239150159.author: a TripAdvisor user
239150159.reviewBody: We were there during heavy rain and it was very good occasion to go visit some forgotten places in the area around, but foggy weather and some roaring apes in the rain forest it was the main experience. Unfriendly shoppers and intrudering guides willing money. May be its heritage of Zapatistic desolation of region, because many tourist are oriented on other places not only to UNESCO super ruins with touristic gross industry. To final disillusion a lack of time for longer visit! Dont go there from SCdLC as one day tourist - it is the worse way to visit this place!

238705356.name: Our first jungle pyramid
238705356.author: a TripAdvisor user
238705356.reviewBody: We loved Palenque.  It is very hard work climbing up (and even more so, down) the steps to the pyramids, but it is worth the effort.  The setting is beautiful and the site is so well maintained by the staff there.  Everything was so green and it was not hard to imagine the Myans enjoying the environment.  This in not just one for two pyramids.  There is many and all are quite different.  Loved it!

238536094.name: Maya civilization versus 21st century tourism
238536094.author: a TripAdvisor user
238536094.reviewBody:
I was fascinated to see for myself what a great Mayan city was actually like in reality, and in spite of the threats of hoards of foreign tourists descending on the site, I found the reality very relaxed and remarkably hassle free. 

There were lots of vendors selling their wares inside the grounds but they were not too intrusive and the dignity of the great spaces were all I had hoped they might be. 

On balance, I arrived slightly apprehensive and over three hours later when I reached the exit, I was very happy indeed with my visit. One note of caution, I did start my visit when the doors opened at 8am!

Robert Morris Nunn
Australia

238472204.name: Hard to leave
238472204.author: a TripAdvisor user
238472204.reviewBody:
Get there early around 8 or 9 am, in the morning you avoid the heat.
Palenque is less crowded than other maya ruins, sometimes you see nobody arond you in some ruins, all you hear is bugio monkeys roaring in the jungle. Once we´re there we forget the time. we go walking around and seeing everything astonished by this wonder in the middle of a jungle.
It´s hard to leave, we want to stay and see everything again and take more and more pictures.
Vans or "colectivos" to and from Palenque city costs less than US$2,00.

237676841.name: Amazing energy
237676841.author: a TripAdvisor user
237676841.reviewBody: Truely amazing energy, views and atmosphere. I would probably not advise going back there after dark, camping out in the main pyramid on the eve of a new phase in human civilization on your own as it leads to being frog marched down the hill at rifle point by 13 guards but hey \u00a360 bribe and its a memory of ....well....a 5012 year phase of many lifetimes :D

236783989.name: Beautiful, interesting and educational!
236783989.author: a TripAdvisor user
236783989.reviewBody:
Some of the best Mayan ruins to visit in Mexico.
The only recognized mausoleum of a Mayan Emperor (Pakal)
Beautiful combination of jungle and original ruins, carefully kept.
Museum of local artifacts, statues and the replica of the thumb of Pakal in an excellent display

236549939.name: Interesting site
236549939.author: a TripAdvisor user
236549939.reviewBody: We found a good guide outside the ruinas site. He only spoke Spanish, but there were English speaking guides as well. The sanitary services were not super great, but as to be expected in this area of Mexico. The guide helped us distinguish between fake and real souvenirs as well.

235709032.name: Beautiful
235709032.author: a TripAdvisor user
235709032.reviewBody: Spectacular and well maintained.Its take about 3 hours to do the tour.Best to have a guide in advance as many are on site and their price range offered to me went from 1000 pesos to 300 pesos/.I suggest you get one from your hotel lodging that comes recommended.No food allowed on site.

235445098.name: Brilliant and Awesome
235445098.author: a TripAdvisor user
235445098.reviewBody: This is one of the best ruin I\'ve ever seen, I definitely recommend to come here as it\'s a very big ruin site. I was stunned by the ruins and glad that I went there. You could hire a guide there if you want to. Recommend you to go early in the morning when it just open, because by the time when I left, there\'s too many tourist and you couldn\'t enjoy the view.

234854720.name: So much to see and experience, So little time!
234854720.author: a TripAdvisor user
234854720.reviewBody: If you don\'t mind an EARLY rise or 5 hour-long winding road  then Palenque is a must. We  squeezed into a van with narrow seats - all 12 of us, and headed for Palenque. Ok, that was not my favorite part of the tour. Especially when our van with little tire tread hit the 450 "topes" or speed bumps on the way there. Yup, that was painful. But like childbirth, once we arrived in Palenque and took in the grandeur of the ancient Mayan Ruins, we seemed to forget the long journey there. You take a short walk through lush vegetation to get to the ruins. Our guide tells us Palenque was built around 100bc. The first temple was for sacrifices - genital mutilation, the bloodier, the more satisfying to the Gods. The blood was collected and cooked and then used as fertilizer. She pointed out a field where games were played. The winner of the ball game she said, would be honored by being beheaded as an offering to the gods. The looser, relegated to a life of shame... We continue to another building where we climb steps and enter through a narrow passage. I\'m overwhelmed to see an ancient sarcophagus, still intact. Our guide points out a stone slab that resembles a bed. She says Pacal, a Mayan king  in his 30\'s and a father three children when was castrated on the slab by his mother as an offering to the gods. Gasps could be heard among the tourists. It was fascinating to hear so many tales as we wandered from building to building. It was interesting to see massive stone carvings and what could be described as a stone portrait gallery that you might find in a castle. Another crowd pleaser - ancient male and female toilets, still stained with urine. Many a picture was taken there of people squatting over the Pre Columbian squares. Palenque is beautifully preserved. As large as it was, our guide says we only saw 2% of it. The other 98% is still covered by dense jungle. The only reason the Spanish didn\'t destroy it is because they didn\'t see it. Palenque  was inhabited for more than 1000 yrs. Why did the civilization end? Our guides says deforestation, over consumption of resources... the crowd goes silent as we contemplate this. I wonder if we\'re destined for the same fate. \nRecommendation: take a good tour on a comfortable bus. Check the tires. Be warned, you depart at 5a from the hotel and return at 10p, left in the city center. Take cool clothes, good shoes, an umbrella, water, sunscreen, a small towel to wipe off the sweat. And next time, I\'ll plan to stay overnight. 2 hours just isn\'t enough time! Not nearly long enough to recover for the 5 hour long ride home.

234230211.name: Amazing Jungle Ruins
234230211.author: a TripAdvisor user
234230211.reviewBody: We visited the ruins on each of the three days we stayed at Palenque. It was so hot and humid we just took our time and leisurely explored the ruins and the surrounding jungle walks. The ruins are fabulous and well worth an overnight bus trip. The tropical gardens around the entrance are lovely. This is also a great place to do your souvenir shopping as the stalls outside the ruins charge a fraction of what was being asked at other places.

231978712.name: A must see attraction!!!
231978712.author: a TripAdvisor user
231978712.reviewBody: This is a must see if you ever find yourself around this part of the world. Unbelievable how much history buried in the jungle.  It\'s a good walk so come prepared for a sweaty day, even with light clothing. Also make sure you go with a very good footwear, as the steps could be very slippery, especially on a wet day.

231545130.name: A very enjoyable experience.
231545130.author: a TripAdvisor user
231545130.reviewBody: It is easy to spend a full day as, this is one of the better Maya Ruin sites. Not commercialized or over run with tourists. Find the smaller trail away from the mowed lawns, and spend time exploring the hidden ruins.This is a great place to spend a casual day exploring, and picture taking. The hiking is easy,camera, sandals and bug repellent needed. Much of the ruins and waterfalls are in the shade of the forest.

230959738.name: Wonderful ruins.
230959738.author: a TripAdvisor user
230959738.reviewBody: We loved these ruins.  They were wonderful.  We weren\'t expecting this.  They were set against the jungle.  Great waterfalls too as we left.  We had been to Tulum---and what that has going is it\'s set against the water---but these were much more impressive.

230024690.name: better than Chichen Itza
230024690.author: a TripAdvisor user
230024690.reviewBody: This place it\'s really preserved in the form that it was found... we liked that we saw the trees growing between the rocks, the energy there and the mistery .... you need to see it in a lifetime... the monkeys are making the music, the iguanas are present.... and \u00b4the most important it\'s not so crowdy

229815832.name: Can\'t miss!
229815832.author: a TripAdvisor user
229815832.reviewBody: This is a MUST if you\'re ever in the area! Such an incredible place, filled with history, nature and beauty!

227808163.name: Amazed!!
227808163.author: a TripAdvisor user
227808163.reviewBody: Rich with history and stunned at how beautiful it is. Would not recommend getting an official tour guide since they over charge to tourist. Your better off getting a tour guide that\'s unofficial since they have the same knowledge, plus it\'s way cheaper.

226793130.name: Magnificent Palenque
226793130.author: a TripAdvisor user
226793130.reviewBody: We enjoyed this visit very much to Palenque, Such a beautiful setting. The archeological site is amazing and love the fact that you can wander through these structures to try and imagine what this place looked like in its day.

226008170.name: Second visit to the ruins, would like to do it again.
226008170.author: a TripAdvisor user
226008170.reviewBody: Get there early! There is limited parking and if you are late getting there, you will need to park on the side of the road and face an up-hill climb. We were pitched guide prices of 500 pesos per person and ended up with a young man of 12 years old who was unlicensed but very knowledgeable about the ruins and the surrounding jungle. He spoke a little English and hope to be a licensed guide in the future... a much easier life than being a camposino in Chiapas. We spent a lot of time exploring the Palace with our guide. He would have kept going but we got worn-out. Our guide had offered his services for the six of us for a total of 150 pesos. We gave him more and I am sure he took home much more that day than did his father. The ruins of Palenque are worth returning to... set in almost park-like grounds.

225886473.name: Misterious marvellous place
225886473.author: a TripAdvisor user
225886473.reviewBody: There\'s only one thing to say... \nIt is an amazing structure that reflects an intriguing culure...\nIt has lots of important elements and only 1% of it has been saved, imagine..

225363207.name: "You have to go there"
225363207.author: a TripAdvisor user
225363207.reviewBody:
Woooow.....

You can go there by collectivos, they drop you up there by the entrance...

You can manage the ruinas in like 1 hour, its amazing, you have a lot to see, lots of amazing photo you can make...

After i have seen everything, i walked down trough a "maya walk way" through the rain forest,
it was like 20 min, and i really liked at, because, you could have a feeling like how the Mayans been living there, and what the first Spain guys was feeling, when they came to this places.

225161901.name: Take a tour to Palenque Ruinas with  Ra\u00fal Silva Acosta
225161901.author: a TripAdvisor user
225161901.reviewBody: We took a private tour from Villahermosa, the gateway of Palenque Ruinas, with the guide Ra\u00fal Silva Acosta. He is the best guide we ever had in Mexico, with good information about the area and also the way there from Villahermosa. He well responded to my husband\'s request that he would also like to see the plants and animals in the area. We enjoyed the museum, the museum shop and the all the ruins 5-6 hours altogether.  The price is very reasonable, less than that of an ordinary group tour mentioned in our guidebook.

224584862.name: Do not take a tour
224584862.author: a TripAdvisor user
224584862.reviewBody: We walked from our hotel since it was only 3km, and took a collectivo back. There are also taxis. Don\'t take a tour, they leave way too late and you can get a guide at the entrance anyway. We spent 4-5 hours there, including the whole area and the museum, but no lunch break. The main ruins have good information posters, though to get maximum benefit you need a guide or a really good guidebook. take the walk back through the jungle and the less-excavated ruins, it is a nice walk brings you out by the museum.

224345897.name: Special place
224345897.author: a TripAdvisor user
224345897.reviewBody: The Ruins are a must.  My suggestion is don\'t enter and exit in the same place.  Enter through  the main area but use the other exit that will make you walk through a path in the forest and will put you near a small river.  You will also be able to see some of the buildings that have been overtaken by the vegetation.  You can grab a "colectivo" from that exit back to town.

224051699.name: One full day dawn to dark is not enough time to see everything.
224051699.author: a TripAdvisor user
224051699.reviewBody: The sophistication of the water and waste systems and the size of the city amazed me. The roads between cities are perfect. Straight from one city to the next 1 meter high and 3 wide and toll booths. HA taxed even way back then.

223200152.name: Mayan Majesty
223200152.author: a TripAdvisor user
223200152.reviewBody: Wow ! The Mayan civilization has just blown me away. This place is truly sophisticated and spectacular. I highly recommend getting a guide. We had Fransisco take our group of 14 on a guided tour and he was so passionate and informative it really made the experience ! Take sturdy shoes with you as there is a lot of walking and plenty of water . The humidity here in this jungle site is a killer. There are shady spots do take advantage where you can . The walking path from the ruins done to the museum is just delightful and the museum is a definite must to finish off your experience. There is a  life size replica of Pakal\'s sarcophagus in there. It will cost you about 20 pesos to get a shuttle back to Palenque centro.

222361305.name: Great place with great museum
222361305.author: a TripAdvisor user
222361305.reviewBody: Wonderfull park with, many Maya ruins inside many trees so very nice shade for resting.\nBeutifull museum with grove tomb and many masks and maya writing.\nA must do when you\'re in the area

222081841.name: That\'s the reason to travel all the way here
222081841.author: a TripAdvisor user
222081841.reviewBody:
The site is amazing and we enjoyed a guided tour that took us through all the history and the little facts that make you really feel what you are seeing.
The only thing that was a bit confusing was the mass of official guides that approached us as soon as we got to the site, everyone offering different lengths of visit at different prices but claiming to have an official price list.
In the end we got an official guide taking only the two of us around for approx 3 hours, in the site and in the jungle, for 700 $ MXN

221894715.name: Mayan Historical Bliss
221894715.author: a TripAdvisor user
221894715.reviewBody: We loved the park and were amazed to find out that only about 2% of the ruins are open to the public.  Choose your guide carefully as some of them were rude and obnoxious, especially when we declined their services.  However, we did overhear a lot of conversations between guides and other tourists and learned a lot about the temples, pyramids and society of the Maya.

221727133.name: Awesome ruins!
221727133.author: a TripAdvisor user
221727133.reviewBody: You can take a guide in the beggining of the park or you can go by yourself. The both are nice because alone you can take your time and see each place when they are more free of people.\nBut this is the only ruin I saw in Mexico which is not placed in a desert, this one is in the middle of the forest.

220691852.name: A must!
220691852.author: a TripAdvisor user
220691852.reviewBody: Palenque is the highlight of the senklassiske Mayan culture. The main building is the Temple of Inscriptions, where Pakals tomb was discovered in 1952. Pakal lived 603-683 AD and was one of the most important rulers of Palenque. It was the first tomb to be discovered throughout the Maya area and changed all theories that the Mayans had only built the pyramid-like platforms to their temples. Then they began to explore other platforms, and since there have been found more than 300 tombs in Palenque and in other Mayan cities, such as Tikal, Copan and Calakmul. The largest building in Palenque\'s Palace, which has several compartments, three courtyards and a tower that was used as an observatory. \n\nIn recent years, suggesting still more of the difficult Mayan characters, and the perception of this great culture seems constantly changing, as more and more deciphered. At times the Mayans been described as a warrior people, then as a culture of peace. Today, the views more nuanced, and culture have also been different in the course of its more than thousand year history. We also know that it was a culture with an unusually high intellectual level. The Mayans were so great astronomers and mathematicians, for example, discovered and used the abstract numerical value zero.

220312411.name: Very nice site
220312411.author: a TripAdvisor user
220312411.reviewBody: Lovely site to walk around, but a bit too many sellers around. The big temple is an excellent climb and gives you a marvelous view!

216708090.name: Little gem in the jungle
216708090.author: a TripAdvisor user
216708090.reviewBody: Not so big as Chichen Itza or Uxmal but really pleasant visit. It\'s possible to climb on the pyramids for a great view of the jungle and the hills. Chiapas landscapes are beautiful and very different from Yucatan.

215807367.name: Best maya site so far
215807367.author: a TripAdvisor user
215807367.reviewBody: We\'ve seen them all: Chichen, Cob\u00e1 and Tulum.. And this one beats them! They are still digging up the rest of the hundreds of temples. Set in pretty jungle settings, you can hear the monkeys yell from the treetops! Fabulous place. Magical. Tip: beat the crowds and go at 08:00 am. 12:00 the busloads of tourists will arrive, and by then you\'re done!

215692306.name: Stunning
215692306.author: a TripAdvisor user
215692306.reviewBody: We went to Palenque after Chichen Itza, and even though Palenque doesn\'t have the huge pyramid, it\'s more impressive because it\'s the whole city. You can go through palaces and temples to houses; all spread over a huge area. The jungle-clad hills surrounding it add to the experience. You can also go into the buildings, unlike C.I.

214956379.name: Beautiful Palenque!
214956379.author: a TripAdvisor user
214956379.reviewBody: This sacred site is one of the most beautiful of the ancient Mayan pyramids, hidden away in the verdant rainforest jungle. A visit to the museum near the site is also a must!

213540862.name: Good, but a long winding bus ride to get there
213540862.author: a TripAdvisor user
213540862.reviewBody: Good, jungly atmosphere, easy to get around, but quite a work out for the quads tackling all the stairs.  It is a long way from anywhere else.  Much easier to and from Villahermosa, but stomach churning from San cristobal

213504123.name: Wow - best with a guide
213504123.author: a TripAdvisor user
213504123.reviewBody: I\u00b4ve been to many different ruins but nothing like this.  It was spectacular.  Hiring a guide added to the experience.   Get there early in the day before it gets too hot.

213158903.name: First through the Gate
213158903.author: a TripAdvisor user
213158903.reviewBody: Absolutely amazing, best Ruins we have seen so far. Get their early and take a Picnic, we spent 5 hours there, so beautiful.

212948287.name: Maybe the best
212948287.author: a TripAdvisor user
212948287.reviewBody:
After having seen Tikal only days beforehand and recently visiting Copan we thought we might find another set of Mayan ruins underwhelming but we were very wrong.
Unlike other ruins here can you get inside some of the buildings. The grounds were in immaculate condition and the site has a good blend of excavated and wild sites. 
Overall it felt like a good blend of the size and wildness of Tikal with the carvings etc of Copan.
We think it was our favourite of the three which is saying something as we loved the other two.
We took a public van from town (15 peso - most wanted 20 though), it cost 28 peso to enter the National Park (didn't seem to be a lot of other areas to visit outside of the ruins) and then 59 peso to enter the ruins and museum. 
We arrived at around 8.45am to try and beat the heat and the tour groups, the latter were already there in big numbers so if you want small crowds, lunchtime in the heat might be better.
We walked the waterfall trail to the museum, they are really nice (and there are some more ruins in the jungle) but it is mean they won't let you swim in them when it is sooooo hot!
Definitely take time to wander through the museum, the masks, stellae and other carvings are awesome and the discovered sacophagous is amazing.
The only negative as some say is the huge amount of vendors selling trinkets throughtout the actual ruins, but considering so many were persuing and buying I guess most visitors don't mind.

211301841.name: A must see
211301841.author: a TripAdvisor user
211301841.reviewBody: If you\'ve travelled this far, you should not miss seeing these ruins. \nAlot of Mexican history to discover.  Tours are easy to book.

210083872.name: Great site, easy access
210083872.author: a TripAdvisor user
210083872.reviewBody: You can access easily the site with a taxi from town. There are 2 entry/exit points. Try to enter though the main gate and exit through the walk in the woods on your way to the museum. The day we went was not crowded, it was on week day, off season. Get a guide if you can as there is lots of history behind it. We used Ernesto, he speaks very good English.

210027863.name: Beautiful ruins in a beautiful setting
210027863.author: a TripAdvisor user
210027863.reviewBody:
Our original plan for a Mayan trek was to focus entirely on the Yucatan Peninsula. But then a fried told us we HAD to see Palenque. His passion convinced us to change our route enough to see the ruins there and we're glad we did. We were instantly struck by how the ruins stand stoically in the middle of some of the lushest and most verdant terrain we've ever seen.

Our visit was in late May, which is when the rainy season begins and heavy precip falls daily. Thankfully it rained that morning then moved on so that our 5 hours on site were dry. Well, 'dry' is a relative term: this is the jungle so prepare for intense humidity, especially if you go in the summer. We come from a humid climate in the US and it was muggy beyond our standards. Plan on several hours at the site because it is really spread out if you want to see everything. Wear good walking shoes with decent grip (you can climb on most of the ruins so good soles will help). Ample water (buy it before you go at an Oxxo store or something, it's pricey at the site), strong sunblock, and plenty of insect repellent are all absolute requirements for a smooth visit. 

At the entrance you will be bombarded by tour guides offering their services and they pounce quickly. Quality differs among the companies stationed all along the parking area and I wasn't aware of any "official" guides like they have at Chichen Itza.  We weren't even offered a map by the park service. So unless you do a lot of research before going, you may want to consider hiring a guide on the site. Most of the tour guides will haggle if you balk at their initial price so give that a shot. We talked ours down by half so it is possible during the slower season.
We ordinarily don't hire guides at sites but we did this time. Ignacio (can't remember the company's name) did a good job, was interesting, and took us on a walk through the jungle as well, telling us about the local vegetation, showing us how to eat termites, and letting us taste the syrup of indigenous jungle fruit. It was also fun to see unexcavated buildings and walls in the jungle so we don't regret hiring him at all.

A lot of people visiting the ruins stay overnight in Palenque town and we can recommend that as a good way to see the ruins. Little collectivo vans with the word "Ruinas" in the window travel to and from the site for 20 pesos apiece all day long. They are usually lined up at the corner of Benito Juarez and Allende in the morning. Streets aren't labeled well there and English isn't common. If you have a smartphone or a tablet, get on Google Maps and save the Palenque map to your device so it can be used offline. That was a lot of help in getting us around town, though Google doesn't map the archaeological site itself.

209937219.name: Great Ruins
209937219.author: a TripAdvisor user
209937219.reviewBody: This was a great place to visit. The ruins are quite impressive and the site was not nearly as crowded as other ruins. It gets quite hot and humid but some relief as you are surrounded by trees throughout.

209193810.name: Fantastic setting and Construction
209193810.author: a TripAdvisor user
209193810.reviewBody: Having toured many of the larger ruins in Mexico I can happily say that this is my favourite. Set on the edge of the mountains and jungle you can see sites weighting for the archaeologists todescend on them. You can easily spend three hours walking around reading the various tourist aids.

208044051.name: Spectacular site!
208044051.author: a TripAdvisor user
208044051.reviewBody: We arrived just when the site opened. This is a very popular site and now it is easy to get there, so it is wise to visit off season or on a weekday early in the morning. The site is beautiful, well cared for, and takes a good two to three hours to visit. There are many vendors in and outside of the site.

206736197.name: Great site but too many people
206736197.author: a TripAdvisor user
206736197.reviewBody: We really did love this site but, even though we arrive at the exact opening time, there were already dozens of buses and shuttles parked with their passengers lined up to enter. We felt a little disappointed--even though we know this is a famous site--that every time we tried to take a photo or wanted a few moments of tranquility to ourselves, a tour group of 25 people walked right in front of us. \n\nDefinitely go visit this amazing ruins site but be forewarned that it\'s generally packed with people.

205841528.name: Quite different than Tikal...
205841528.author: a TripAdvisor user
205841528.reviewBody: We\'ve recently visited both Tikal in Guatemala and now Palenque in Mexico. Although both are Mayan, both have similar architecture, that\'s where similarities end... the settings are quite different, the vastness of Palenque is quite impressive as well. The fact that you can go into certain temples is also quite interesting. It\'s also a good to point out that the museum has great pieces on display and a great replica of the cercofagus found inside one of the main temples. Hope this review was helpful!!!

203055426.name: Climb, baby, climb
203055426.author: a TripAdvisor user
203055426.reviewBody: The views from the ruins are amazing. Get there early, bring lots of water, and comfortable shoes so that you can climb as many ruins as possible. There are some signs, but it\'s best to read up about the site and bring a map if you opt out of a tour. The museum has information in Spanish and English and is a great way to end your visit.

202157436.name: breathtaking view!!
202157436.author: a TripAdvisor user
202157436.reviewBody:
It is amazing how something built hundreds of years ago is still here..and JUST being discovered...
it is only 2% of all the pyramids of the area and they are gorgeous!!... 

you have to go with comfortable shows and be ready to walk..

the tour guys tell you to take 4 hours, that's WAY TOO MUCH! i stayed like 2 1/2 and was more than enough!!!

it is free for students so don't forget your ID !!

202088553.name: Ruins worth visiting
202088553.author: a TripAdvisor user
202088553.reviewBody: Despite the midday heat burning down on us, Palenque is an impressive place to visit, and has more of a wild feel to it than Chichen Itza. Be aware that there is not much shade, so if you have problems with heat and direct sunlight, time your visit so that you get there early in the morning.

201077942.name: WoW
201077942.author: a TripAdvisor user
201077942.reviewBody: The Palenque ruins are for me better than Cichen Itza. I love the nature around it, the price is less than 60 peso and you can see the pyramid, observatorium and they are easy to come (with collectivo from the center of Palenque fot 20 peso). Enjoy

199675585.name: Amazing
199675585.author: a TripAdvisor user
199675585.reviewBody: These ruins beat chichen itza for us as their location and un- touched nature are stunning. Go at opening time to get the place for yourself -well worth it x

199418976.name: greatest collection of unearthed Mayan ruins
199418976.author: a TripAdvisor user
199418976.reviewBody: Numerous unearthed structures, step portions which have had to be rebuilt, provide a glimpse back into the Mayan culture. If you pick up a guide book or do some internet reading ahead of time hiring a guide when you are there really isn\'t necessary. There a many sing boards revealing what a typical visitor wants to know. The parking lot is packed with vendors, but that\'s no different than sites anywhere else in the world. While in recent years parts have been closed off for archeological or safety reasons, this does not take away from the wonder of early civilization architecture. Taking the forest paths reveal more structure yet to be unearthed and massive trees. Plan a long day. Best to visit in the morning because by noon this area heats up. Bring lots of water.

199237975.name: Once Upon a Time...
199237975.author: a TripAdvisor user
199237975.reviewBody: We visited as a group of 30 mature-aged Scandinavians from Finland. We managed to get may be the most professional guide Victor, who has worked as an archaeologist over 40 years on this site. We discovered once again how the time is passing but the human beings are the same. In the morning the weather is not to hot. This site is a MUST!

198967902.name: Amazing
198967902.author: a TripAdvisor user
198967902.reviewBody: What else can I add? The ruins were well explained by panels in Spanish and English. We got there early on a Sunday morning and it wasn\'t all that busy.\nThe museum is excellent, mostly in both Spanish & English.

198900958.name: Richard visits Palenque Ruins
198900958.author: a TripAdvisor user
198900958.reviewBody: Fabulous well maintained ruins with nearby jungle walk to the museum. A little disappointed with the large number of vendors but were not aggressive. .

197436668.name: Beautiful Location and Amazing Ruins
197436668.author: a TripAdvisor user
197436668.reviewBody: Great place to spend the afternoon and early evening. The ruins are well preserved but seem to be in a relatively natural state. The surrounding mountains and jungle acentuate the amazing vistas and add to the magical feeling of this special place. Just go, you won\'t be disapointed!

197183590.name: How to visit Palenque independently with a car
197183590.author: a TripAdvisor user
197183590.reviewBody:
Take it as a given that Palenque is a must-see. You will gawp in amazement. Go before they start stopping you from climbing these ruins. I can't add any more to the other several hundred reviews about them! They are incredible.

But I spent ages trying to work out what to do if you were driving yourself there. So having done it, this is what I learnt.

Palenque ruins are in the Palenque National Park (unsurprisingly!). There is one road into the Park from Palenque town & it is signposted. Just keep driving up it. You will pass by hotels and when they stop you will get to a barrier where you have to pay an entrance fee to get into the National Park, regardless of whether you intend to roam through it over and above seeing the ruins. I read an older review that said you can avoid this fee if you say you are just visiting the ruins - you can't anymore or at least the man taking the money said we had to pay. Full stop. (Although the Mexican visitor in the car in front got through without paying?!)

Once you have paid, carry on up the road. Further up the road you will see a car park and museum on your right. You can park, pay to see the ruins, visit the museum (included in the ruins entrance fee) and then walk across the road & up the very steep path to the ruins taking in the beautiful waterfalls. You would then walk around the ruins and come back down to your car. But I think it's best not to do it this way around. So, my advice is to keep going up the road until you come to the main entrance where the road terminates. There is parking and usually locals helping you find a space. Parking is free but whoever lynches onto you to help you park will ask for some money to look after your car. We politely declined (made sure no valuables were visible before arriving) and our car was fine when we returned.

Once you've parked, pay the entrance fee and off you go. When you get to the back of the site (at this point you've pretty much seen it but you can come back), you'll see a pathway to the museum. Take it - the museum is worth it & the walk down past some beautiful waterfalls and the odd extra ruin is lovely. The museum closes quite early (I can't remember exactly but I think it's 4pm) so be sure to get there with at least half an hour to see it. 

When you have finished in the museum, you can walk back up to the ruins (just have your entrance ticket ready to show). You don't have to walk back up the long, steep path you walked down - there is a shorter path. Whist it is still a steep path, the shortcut avoids the waterfalls so it's much shorter. Take it slowly & it's manageable. Look for the sign forking off to the right for the ruins shortly after starting the ascent. It's not as pretty as the longer way down but you've seen that once (so take all the snaps you want on the way down as you won't be walking back past it)!

If you really can't face the walk up and you've finished in the ruins, you can just stand at the side of the road outside the museum & cabs or collectivos will stop & give you a ride back up to your car for a fee.

We drove from Becan, leaving just after 9am and got to Palenque at about 1 - 2pm. This was enough time to wander casually around the ruins, get to the museum before it closed and get back into the ruins & out before they closed. Also, the crowds must have dwindled as it wasn't too bad. We had no intention of taking extra walks in the National Park - you would need a whole day if this is your plan.

We didn't take a guide, just read up about the site beforehand. There are plaques written in English giving you basic details of the structures so we found those along with some prior knowledge was enough and we could go at our own pace.   

One final tip, if you stop to refuel at the station at the end of the National Park road (if you turn right, you'll see the station on the right). Watch out for a scam - one fills & another chats to you to stop you looking at the pump and the amount of fuel going in. We asked them to fill it up but the man filling stopped at 100pesos and asked for payment. We said no, full please & the chatting man keeps chatting making sure you don't look at the pump. At the end, the filling man asked for 100pesos from the 'first' filling plus the new total on the pump which was 200pesos, so 300 pesos in total. But based on the fuel in the car he couldn't have reset the pump after 100pesos, simply carried on putting another 100pesos in so a total of 200pesos went in but he wanted 300pesos. Because the chatting man had distracted us from watching the fuel pump, we had to pay what they asked for. Another station in Cancun tried this trick but by ignoring the chatting man and making sure the pump was reset after the first filling, we didn't get caught out again.

I hope this 'essay' on visiting the site by yourself helps other independent travellers - I might be biased but IMO this is the best way to see these outstanding ruins.

196581374.name: Allow tons of time - ideally split over two days
196581374.author: a TripAdvisor user
196581374.reviewBody:
The site is gigantic and I didn't expect such extent, variety and beauty. You might want to come one first time in the late afternoon and hire a guide and come again the day after to enjoy at your own pace before the heat and crowds hit. Obviously this is much more costly.

The guides are useful as there are many parts still unexcavated and in the jungle and you may be more likely to see it all with a guide

The museum is a little gem which I think we didn't enjoy to its right value as we were so tired after a whole day of walking around the ruins. In fact it may make sense to see it first as we were frustrated to read all about the Temple of the Inscriptions and the tumbs, and we would have appreciated it better if we had seen the sarcophage in the museum first.

Note that you can get to and from the ruins super easily with combis/collectivos and there is no need for a taxi.

There are two way to exit: the entrance next to the Skull Temple, and the museum exit which is at the end of a beautiful walk through the jungle, that takes you through various additional ruins and next to a waterfall.

An amazing site

196350254.name: Our second visit, well worth the trip
196350254.author: a TripAdvisor user
196350254.reviewBody: We were surprised that they did not open till 8AM, last time we got in at 7. The earlier the better, avoid the crowds and the day will still be cool by the time you finish.  We had a great guide, fantastic with kids and never got tired of answering thousands of questions.  Beautiful day, beautiful ruins and beautiful memories.  Well worth the visit.

196333579.name: Wonderful experience
196333579.author: a TripAdvisor user
196333579.reviewBody: Five of us traveled by bus(many curves and topes) from San Cristobal to Palenque and it took 7 hours because of a blockade.  The ruins are remarkable and it was well worth it. We hired Ernesto, an English speaking guide, for a walk through the jungle (where we saw more unexplored ruins) and through the ruins themselves.  This place is not to be missed! The guide was especially helpful.  Because we stayed the entire day, we became quite hungry and it\'s difficult to find a decent lunch without walking quite a ways.  Take a sandwich!  The museum is also spectacular.  Many folks go for only a few hours, but for us, we needed the full day to take it all in.

196111906.name: It is the Paris of the Maya
196111906.author: a TripAdvisor user
196111906.reviewBody:
We (there was six of us) booked a tour of Palenque through Maya Tours - which was a mistake.  If I had it to do over again, I’d have just taken a cab.  There is a taxi stand outside the gate of the site. 
We were picked-up at our hotel, and driven to the site.  There were two entrance fees - one to the preserve/park and one to the actual site (which included the museum).  Outside the gate, we paid $85 (US) for a tour guide (tour length was to be two hours - although it went a bit longer than that).  The lady was knowlegable, and her english was very good, but she was clearly on a schedule and toward the end of the time was impatient for us to move faster.
Palenque is a very large and park-like setting.  It covers a valley and several hillsides.  There is a lot of water flowing through the site, and (while we were there) significant humidity - which lent a kind of softening haze to the area.
Palenque is the type of site that divides a tour group.  The casual tourist, stopping by to see a world historical site, could spend a happy two or three hours & move on.  People who are more ‘into’ Mayan history & architecture could easily spend a happy two or three days here. 
Do not skip the museum!  It’s very interesting and has a great exhibit and explaination of the tomb.
Like the the other ‘big‘ or ‘very popular‘ Mayan sites (like Chichen Itza); Palenque has a large number of people selling trinkets in and around the site.  Inside, the sellers are supposed to have some ancesteral Mayan connection, outside - who knows.  Most of these trinkets appeared (to me) to be the same mass-produced items that could be found in shops all over at half the price.  To me, it really distracts from the site.  It would be one thing if they were selling hand crafted traditional peices - but, that is simply not the case.

195941234.name: Half day at the Mayan ruins
195941234.author: a TripAdvisor user
195941234.reviewBody: Amazing collection of buildings to see, hundreds of additional ones still submerged in the surrounding jungle. Go early to avoid the crowds and more importantly the heat!

195431956.name: A must see site!
195431956.author: a TripAdvisor user
195431956.reviewBody: Even if you are not a great Mayan ruin fan, the Palenque ruins are not to be missed. Really beautyful and interesting ruins in a wonderful tropical forest setting and a nice museum just outside the site itself. Unfortunately some of the main buidings are now closed for the public, and can not be climbed. But it\'s still worth the trip.

194856835.name: Beautiful
194856835.author: a TripAdvisor user
194856835.reviewBody: Nicely restored, beautiful grounds, great variety of ruins. You can stop by for a few hours or easily spend a few days roaming this site. Some of the stone carvings are still there as are a few small faded mural pieces. The structures are stunning. There are a lot of steps to climb here, so wear comfy shoes, bring a sun hat and water and your camera. There are also a lot of magnificent shade trees to relax under if you just want to sit and gaze at history. Guides are abundant, informative and affordable if you want that, and it is also easy to navigate on your own, and at your own pace. Make sure your guide speaks your language comfortably as there is a great variety.\n It\'s easy to get to from town. The collectivos take off from near the bus station (20p) or you can likely arrange one from your hotel. Or stay out by the park and walk or ride a collectivo. Lots of variety nearby to choose from nearby...high end to hippie utopia.

194740334.name: Mexico\'s top ruins
194740334.author: a TripAdvisor user
194740334.reviewBody: We loved the Palenque ruins.  We have now visited all five of Mexico\'s top ruins (Chichen Itza, Uxmal, Monte Alban, the Pyramids and Palenque.)  Palenque rivals the Pyramids in interesting.  It\'s well worth the special trip to Palenque town.  A side note.  I would advocate staying in the La Canada section of the town - not out on the road to the ruins. The town is nothing special but it\'s not that bad.  We roamed around at night and ate well at local restaurants.

194636089.name: Palenque Mayan ruins
194636089.author: a TripAdvisor user
194636089.reviewBody: This is the second Mayan ruin we have visited and Palenque is definitely a required visit.\nThe tour guides know their stuff and the tours is wonderful. Avoid Sundays, as it is free for\nMexicans, hence can get crowded.

194564362.name: Amazing site, verdant and magical
194564362.author: a TripAdvisor user
194564362.reviewBody: This Mayan ruin site is special. Although throngs are there the dignity and calm remain. Make sure you get a guide , additional fee 500p+. There are many languages available and little in the way of self guide tools. We were roaring through in 2 hours...not nearly enough time.\n\nIf you can, arrange your travel so that you arrive at the ruins early - birds and monkeys disappear as the heat and crowds build. We were based in puerto escondido and this site is absolutely worth the extra effort...overnight buses both direction

193826747.name: Magical place
193826747.author: a TripAdvisor user
193826747.reviewBody: I adored this maya site involved by the jungle setting. It\'s truly peaceful and magical, worth the trip to Palenque, it\'s really something special.

193793623.name: very interesting in history
193793623.author: a TripAdvisor user
193793623.reviewBody: if you are interested in Maya history, you can\u00b4t miss this place,. i think is the most beautiful place with ruins in the jungle, you have to hire a guide in order to understand the place if not you can miss a lot of information

193726255.name: the best ruins in mexico
193726255.author: a TripAdvisor user
193726255.reviewBody:
It was wonderful!!! the best ruins in Mexico that I ever seen, its a 3/4 hours visit, we could see all the jungle, plants, butterflies, we can heard the loudy saraguato monkey.

You can see a Museum site near with more information.

To get there are other options like the "combis", public transportation for $20 pesos, you can get the ruinas/centro circuit (ADO bus station is in that circuit)

We could leave ours backpacks in the top entrance, then at the museum site, I recommend the museum site. The top entrance they asked for $20 pesos. We dont know if its a official cost.

Take care about the people who offers a turism guide, not at all are official guides.

193277533.name: The Best!
193277533.author: a TripAdvisor user
193277533.reviewBody: Whatever you do do not skip the Palenque Ruins.  My wife and I are taking a few years to travel around the world.  We started in Mexico and have visited almost all the major ruin sites.  This one was by far our favorite (Tekal was a close second).  We loved the fact that you can wander around and climb ever pyramid in the complex, except one.  Get here early and bring plenty of food and water.  It got very hot during our visit and we went through 2Lt.s of water throughout the day.  The snack and food places out front are a little over priced and did not look too appetizing.  So packing some sandwiches was a much better option for us.  Be wary of taking expensive taxis or tour buses, there are plenty of colectivo vans driving down the main road or out of town all day.  Save a few bucks and take a colectivo instead.  Hopefully this was helpful and enjoy the ruins!

193174938.name: Highlight of our tour
193174938.author: a TripAdvisor user
193174938.reviewBody: We were on a 3-week tour of Mayan ruins.  I had read a few books on the Mayan ruins beforehand.  Palenque was the one I was most looking forward to seeing.  It was amazing.  Even the rain didn\'t "dampen" the experience.  The heavy rains made the waterfall even more spectacular.  We were all disappointed that the museum was closed because of the rain.  It was unfathomable to us that they built a museum in a rainforest which has to close because of the rain.

193165840.name: Mayans in the Mists
193165840.author: a TripAdvisor user
193165840.reviewBody: We visited the Palenque ruins in the early morning. The mist over the site added to the atmosphere as did the echoing growls of a male howler monkey nearby. The restored structures were impressive and these ruins were our favourite of the several we visited on our Mexico tour. There are still many mounds in the jungle yet to be investigated, giving an impression of the site that the early explorers discovered. We had an excellent guide who brought the place alive to us, including the highlights in the nearby museum, well worth a visit. The fibre-glass replica of the main sarcophagus found on the site is well done and worth spending time examining in detail.  The crowds began to arrive around 11am, so we would recommend staying at a nearby hotel (e.g. Chan-Kah) and arriving early.

193115311.name: Don\'t miss it!
193115311.author: a TripAdvisor user
193115311.reviewBody: A visit to Palenque is a must for anyone interested in the rich and varied Mayan culture which existed throughout this area. We met the former administrator of this site when she was assigned to Chichen Itza. She suggested that we visit during the end of January or February, when the weather is less hot and humid and the off-season crowds are less numerous. Several people we met in San Cristobal informed us that, although the ruins were open on Mondays,  the museum was closed, and we rescheduled our visit for Tuesday. Avoid visiting on the weekend if at all possible, even during the off-season.The site is extremely well-cared for with accessible paths for people with physical issues like my husband. An official guide is a must. You can identify them by their badges. A colectivo runs between the ruins and the museum, which is small but very worth visiting. There is an especially interesting exhibit and series of videos on the discovery of Pakal, the most famous Mayan ruler.

193003127.name: Absolutely amazing
193003127.author: a TripAdvisor user
193003127.reviewBody:
We have been to a number of ruin sites in Mexico over the past years, Ek-Balam, Coba, Tulum and Chichen Itza. Some might say "if you've seen one, you've seen them all".  We are so glad we did not pay attention to this. Our visit to Palenque was part of a 9 day, 3 state, 6 city adventure circling the Yucatan Pennisula but it would be wortwhile going there anyway. 
The size of the recovered portion of the ruins is about 4 times that of Tulum with so many more temples, etc. to see. But more than that, it is the feeling you get while there, magical and alive. 
After spending about 3.5 hours touring, climbing temples and taking pictures, we decided to take an exit that was different from the one where we entered. The sign said museo salida. We are so happy we took that path as we came across some beautiful waterfalls of which we were not aware. 
One word of caution though, we came out the exit near the museo and had to walk 2.5 km uphill to get back to our car. If you do this path, do not turn down the offers of a drive from the shuttle bus drivers.
Also, take lots of SD cards and batteries, we took so many pictures,  both batteries ran out.

192872776.name: Impressive archeological site
192872776.author: a TripAdvisor user
192872776.reviewBody: Impressive archeological site with the ingressive jungles and picturesque views of the remnants of the Maya city against the background of the green jungles and fog. In some parts there are too many people that impedes enjoying the sightseeing. Do not miss a very good museum with plenty of impressive displays.

192043101.name: Superb!
192043101.author: a TripAdvisor user
192043101.reviewBody: This is a stunning place to visit!  Hire a local guide and your visit will be first-class.  We hired Virgin for 2 hours and he spent over 2.5 hours with us.  An excellent guide in all respects as well as an excellent speaker of the English language.  He also speaks Mayan and does not try to overwhelm you.  Take the collectivio to the ruins and save the price of the van/guide that are hustled around town...

191826373.name: Amazing place
